definition.en: A paper polygon (often a hexagon) folded so it can be flexed to reveal different faces or patterns.
definition.zh: 一种纸质多边形（常见为六边形），通过特殊折叠可以“翻折/扭转”来展示不同的面或图案。

examples.en: We made a flexagon in math club and discovered hidden colors on the inside faces.
examples.zh: 我们在数学社团做了一个flexagon，翻折后发现里面的面有隐藏的颜色。

examples.en: A flexagon looks simple, but it can reveal several faces when you flex it.
examples.zh: flexagon看起来很简单，但翻折时可以展示好几个不同的面。

extraExplanation: flexagon 是由 “flex”（弯曲、翻折）+ “-gon”（多边形，如 polygon）构成的词。最经典的是 trihexaflexagon（“三面六边翻折片”），常被用作数学与折纸（origami）科普，展示拓扑与几何的趣味。
在英语里它属于相对小众但标准的数学/折纸词汇；日常聊天不常用，更多出现在课堂、科普书、手工教程或数学爱好者社区中。

summary.en: flexanimous means adaptable and willing to change your mind (a very rare word).
summary.zh: flexanimous 指思想态度上很能变通、愿意改变看法（非常罕用的词）。

definition.en: (Rare) willing to change your mind; adaptable or open-minded, especially in attitude or judgment.
definition.zh: （罕用）思想或态度上愿意变通、易于调整；通达、开明（尤指判断与立场上）。

examples.en: A good mediator needs to be flexanimous, able to see both sides without stubbornness.
examples.zh: 优秀的调解者要足够 flexanimous，能不固执地看见双方的立场。

examples.en: She stayed flexanimous during the discussion and revised her opinion when new facts appeared.
examples.zh: 讨论中她保持 flexanimous 的态度，新事实出现时就调整了看法。

extraExplanation: 这个词非常少见，主要出现在较早期的英语中。它由拉丁语词根组合而来：flex-（弯曲、可变通）+ animus（心灵、意志、态度），字面意思接近“心意可弯、可转”。现代英语更常用 open-minded、flexible、adaptable 来表达同样意思。使用 flexanimous 会显得非常书面、古雅，适合文学化或刻意追求罕见词汇的语境。

summary.en: “Flexed” usually means muscles tightened/bent, or it is the past form of “flex.” In slang, it can mean “showed off.”
summary.zh: “flexed”常指（肌肉）绷紧/弯曲，也是 flex 的过去式；俚语中可指“炫耀/显摆”。

definition.en: Having the muscles tightened or bent to show strength or effort; tensed.
definition.zh: （肌肉）绷紧的；（为显示力量或用力而）弯曲用力的。

examples.en: He stood with his arms flexed, showing his biceps.
examples.zh: 他站着时手臂绷紧，秀出二头肌。

examples.en: Her jaw was flexed, and she looked angry.
examples.zh: 她咬紧下巴，显得很生气。

definition.en: Past tense/past participle of “flex”: to bend a part of your body or to tighten a muscle.
definition.zh: flex 的过去式/过去分词：弯曲（身体部位）；绷紧（肌肉）。

examples.en: He flexed his fingers to warm them up.
examples.zh: 他活动（弯曲）手指给它们暖身。

examples.en: She flexed her shoulders before lifting the box.
examples.zh: 她在抬箱子前绷紧/活动了一下肩膀。

definition.en: (Slang, especially online) Bragged or showed off; displayed something to impress others.
definition.zh: （俚语，常见于网络）炫耀；显摆（为给别人留下深刻印象）。

examples.en: He flexed his new shoes on Instagram.
examples.zh: 他在 Instagram 上晒（炫耀）了新鞋。

examples.en: Don’t flex your grades—just help your friends study.
examples.zh: 别拿成绩炫耀了，帮朋友一起学习就好。

extraExplanation: “flex” 原意是“弯曲、屈曲”（来自拉丁语 *flectere*，意为“弯”）。现代口语里的 “to flex” 发展出“展示肌肉/实力”的意思，因此在网络语境中常指“炫耀”。
注意语感区别：在健身语境里 “flexed” 多偏中性（肌肉绷紧/展示）；在社交媒体语境里往往带一点“显摆”的意味，语气可能褒贬取决于上下文。

summary.en: “Flexes” means “bends/tightens (a muscle or object)” or, informally, “shows off.” It can also be the plural noun for acts of showing off.
summary.zh: “Flexes”可指“使（肌肉）绷紧/使物体弯曲”，也可作口语表示“炫耀、显摆”；还可作名词复数指“炫耀的行为”。

definition.en: (third-person singular of “flex”) to bend or tighten a muscle, or to move something so it bends.
definition.zh: （“flex”的第三人称单数）使肌肉绷紧/用力；或使某物弯曲。

examples.en: He flexes his fingers before playing the piano.
examples.zh: 他在弹钢琴前会活动并绷紧手指。

examples.en: The dancer flexes her feet to point her toes.
examples.zh: 舞者绷紧脚部来伸展脚趾。

examples.en: This plastic flexes easily without breaking.
examples.zh: 这种塑料很容易弯曲而不易断裂。

definition.en: (informal) to show off in a confident, sometimes boastful way—often by displaying money, status, skills, or appearance.
definition.zh: （非正式）炫耀；显摆（常指展示金钱、地位、能力或外表，带点自夸意味）。

examples.en: He flexes his new watch on social media.
examples.zh: 他在社交媒体上晒新手表炫耀。

examples.en: She flexes about her perfect test score.
examples.zh: 她拿满分成绩来显摆。

examples.en: Stop flexing and just help us finish the project.
examples.zh: 别再炫耀了，来帮我们把项目做完。

definition.en: (plural, informal) displays of strength or “showing off,” especially online.
definition.zh: （复数，非正式）炫耀的行为/表现（尤其指在网上“晒”出来的那种）。

examples.en: His posts are mostly flexes about expensive cars.
examples.zh: 他的帖子基本都是在晒豪车炫耀。

examples.en: That comment felt like one of those unnecessary flexes.
examples.zh: 那条评论给人的感觉就是没必要的显摆。

extraExplanation: “flex”在口语和网络语境里很常见，意思从“肌肉用力/弯曲”延伸到“展示自己很强、很有钱或很有面子”。这种“炫耀”的语气有时带贬义（让人觉得在装），但在朋友之间也可能是半开玩笑的夸赞。
注意搭配：flex + body part（flex his arms）；flex + object/status（flex a new phone / flex wealth）。也常见结构：a flex（一次炫耀）、weird flex（奇怪的炫耀，常接“but ok”）。

summary.en: “Flexibilities” is the plural of “flexibility,” often used to mean multiple areas of freedom or options to adapt, especially in business or policy contexts.
summary.zh: “flexibilities”是“flexibility”的复数，常指多项可调整的空间或变通选项，尤其常见于商务与政策语境。

definition.en: The ability to adapt, change plans, or handle different situations easily (plural form).
definition.zh: 适应变化、调整计划或应对不同情况的能力（复数形式）。

examples.en: The contract allows flexibilities in delivery dates if supply is delayed.
examples.zh: 如果供货延迟，这份合同允许在交货日期上有一定的灵活性。

examples.en: Good managers build flexibilities into their schedules.
examples.zh: 好的管理者会在日程安排中留出灵活性。

definition.en: Different options or degrees of freedom in how something can be done (plural form).
definition.zh: 做某事时可选择的不同方式或自由度（复数形式）。

examples.en: The new policy offers flexibilities for remote work and flexible hours.
examples.zh: 新政策为远程办公和弹性工时提供了多种灵活安排。

examples.en: Teachers need flexibilities to meet students’ needs.
examples.zh: 教师需要一定的变通空间来满足学生的需求。

definition.en: The ability of the body (muscles/joints) to bend or move easily (plural form, less common).
definition.zh: 身体（肌肉/关节）弯曲或活动自如的能力（复数形式，较少见）。

examples.en: Yoga improves strength and flexibilities over time.
examples.zh: 瑜伽会随着时间提升力量和柔韧性。

extraExplanation: “flexibilities”是“flexibility”的复数。日常口语里，“flexibility”更常用作不可数名词（表示总体的灵活性）。在商务、政策、制度等语境中，人们更常用复数“flexibilities”来强调“多项具体的灵活安排/变通条款/可选空间”。
写作提示：如果你想表达“需要更多灵活性”，通常说“more flexibility”；如果想强调“有很多可调整的点/选项”，可以说“more flexibilities”或“greater flexibilities (in the rules/plan)”。

summary.en: Flexibility means being able to bend (physically) or adapt (in plans, rules, or thinking) without breaking down.
summary.zh: Flexibility 指“柔韧性/灵活性”：既可指身体或材料的可弯曲性，也可指计划、规则或思维上的适应与通融。

definition.en: the ability to bend easily without breaking; physical suppleness
definition.zh: （身体或材料的）柔韧性；可弯曲而不易断裂的能力

examples.en: Yoga can improve flexibility in your hips and shoulders.
examples.zh: 瑜伽可以提高你髋部和肩部的柔韧性。

examples.en: This plastic has flexibility, so it won’t crack in the cold.
examples.zh: 这种塑料很有柔韧性，所以在寒冷环境下不容易开裂。

definition.en: the ability to adapt or change plans easily; willingness to adjust
definition.zh: （做事/安排的）灵活性；适应变化、愿意调整的能力

examples.en: Working parents often need flexibility in their schedules.
examples.zh: 上班的父母常常需要时间安排上的灵活性。

examples.en: The team showed flexibility by changing the design at the last minute.
examples.zh: 团队在最后一刻更改设计，展现了灵活应变的能力。

definition.en: the quality of being open-minded and not rigid in rules or thinking
definition.zh: （规则/思维的）不僵化；通融性；不固执

examples.en: A good manager balances clear rules with flexibility.
examples.zh: 好的管理者会在明确规则与灵活通融之间取得平衡。

extraExplanation: 词源上，flexibility 来自拉丁语词根 flex-（“弯曲”），所以它既能指“身体/材料能弯”，也引申为“做事方式能转弯”＝能适应变化、不会死板。
常见搭配：flexibility in schedules（时间安排的灵活性）、flexibility at work（工作灵活度）、improve flexibility（提高柔韧性）、lack flexibility（缺乏灵活性）。

summary.en: Flexibilization means the process of making something more flexible or adaptable, often used in policy, business, or labor contexts.
summary.zh: Flexibilization 指“使……更灵活/更可适应的过程”，常用于政策、商业或劳动领域语境。

definition.en: the process of making something more flexible, adaptable, or less strictly controlled (especially rules, work arrangements, or labor markets)
definition.zh: （使）更灵活、更可适应或管控更少的过程（尤指规则、工作安排或劳动力市场）

examples.en: The company’s flexibilization of work schedules helped parents balance family and job responsibilities.
examples.zh: 公司对工作时间的灵活化帮助家长更好地平衡家庭与工作责任。

examples.en: Some economists argue that labor-market flexibilization can reduce unemployment, while critics worry about job security.
examples.zh: 一些经济学家认为劳动力市场的灵活化能降低失业率，但批评者担心工作保障会下降。

definition.en: the process of allowing materials, systems, or designs to bend or change shape more easily
definition.zh: （材料、系统或设计）更容易弯曲或改变形状的过程

examples.en: Flexibilization of the plastic improved its performance in cold weather.
examples.zh: 对塑料进行柔性化处理提升了它在寒冷天气中的性能。

extraExplanation: “flexibilization”多用于学术或政策语境，尤其常见于经济学、社会学与公共政策讨论（如“labor-market flexibilization”）。在日常英语中，人们更常说“make something more flexible”“increase flexibility”或直接用“flexibility”。
构词上：flexible（灵活的）+ -ize（使……化）→ flexibilize（使更灵活）+ -ation（……的过程/结果）→ flexibilization（灵活化/灵活化过程）。

summary.en: Flexibilize means to make something more flexible or easier to adjust, especially in business or policy contexts.
summary.zh: Flexibilize 指“使……更灵活、更易调整”，尤其常见于商业或政策语境。

definition.en: to make something more flexible; to allow it to change or adapt more easily
definition.zh: 使……更灵活；使……更容易调整或适应

examples.en: The company tried to flexibilize work hours so parents could start earlier or later.
examples.zh: 公司试图让工作时间更灵活，这样家长可以更早或更晚开始上班。

examples.en: Some countries flexibilize labor laws to help employers hire more quickly.
examples.zh: 一些国家会让劳动法更灵活，以帮助雇主更快招聘。

extraExplanation: “flexibilize”在日常英语里相对少见，更常见、更自然的说法是“make (something) flexible”或“increase flexibility”。在商业、政策、劳工与经济学语境中更可能看到“flexibilize”（如“flexibilize the labor market / labor laws”）。
常见相关名词是“flexibilization”（灵活化），多用于正式写作或学术/新闻语体。

summary.en: “Flexibilized” means “made more flexible,” often by loosening rules or structures (formal/business usage).
summary.zh: “flexibilized”意为“被变得更灵活”，常指放宽规则或结构（较正式/商业用语）。

definition.en: (Past tense/past participle of flexibilize) to make something more flexible; to loosen rules, structure, or limits so it can adapt more easily.
definition.zh: （flexibilize 的过去式/过去分词）使……更有弹性；放宽规则、结构或限制，让其更容易适应变化。

examples.en: The company flexibilized its work schedule to support parents.
examples.zh: 公司把工作时间安排变得更灵活，以支持有孩子的员工。

examples.en: Many governments have flexibilized labor regulations to encourage hiring.
examples.zh: 许多政府放宽了劳动法规，以鼓励企业雇用员工。

examples.en: We flexibilized the plan after new information arrived.
examples.zh: 新信息出现后，我们把计划调整得更有弹性。

definition.en: Describing something that has been made more flexible (often used in business, policy, or technical writing).
definition.zh: 描述“已经被变得更灵活”的事物（常见于商业、政策或技术类写作）。

examples.en: A flexibilized supply chain can respond faster to demand changes.
examples.zh: 更具弹性的供应链能更快应对需求变化。

examples.en: They proposed a flexibilized approach to training.
examples.zh: 他们提出了一种更灵活的培训方式。

extraExplanation: “flexibilize / flexibilized”常见于商务、管理与公共政策语境（例如“flexibilized labor market”劳动力市场更灵活化），语气偏正式、偏“行话”。日常英语里更常用 make … more flexible, loosen, relax rules, increase flexibility 等表达。

summary.en: A flexibilizer is an additive that makes a material more flexible and less likely to crack.
summary.zh: flexibilizer 指让材料更柔软、更有弹性、降低开裂风险的添加剂。

definition.en: a substance or additive used to make a material more flexible (for example, making plastic, rubber, paint, or concrete less stiff)
definition.zh: （材料）柔韧剂；增柔剂：用于让材料更柔软、更有弹性的物质或添加剂（如塑料、橡胶、涂料或混凝土等）

examples.en: This coating includes a flexibilizer to prevent cracking in cold weather.
examples.zh: 这种涂层含有柔韧剂，以防在寒冷天气里开裂。

examples.en: The manufacturer added a flexibilizer to improve the film’s bendability.
examples.zh: 厂家加入了增柔剂来提升薄膜的可弯曲性。

extraExplanation: “flexibilizer”在日常英语中不常见，更常见的表达是“plasticizer（增塑剂）”或“flexibility additive（提高柔韧性的添加剂）”。在材料与化工语境里，它强调“让材料更柔韧、减少脆裂”的功能，常用于产品说明书、技术资料或实验记录中。

summary.en: “Flexibilizes” means “makes something more flexible or adaptable.”
summary.zh: “flexibilizes”表示“使……更灵活/更有适应性”。

definition.en: (third-person singular of flexibilize) to make something flexible or more adaptable; to increase flexibility in a system, rule, schedule, or material.
definition.zh: （flexibilize 的第三人称单数）使……更灵活/更有弹性；提高某个制度、规定、安排或材料的灵活性。

examples.en: The company flexibilizes work hours to support parents and caregivers.
examples.zh: 公司把工时安排变得更灵活，以支持有孩子或需要照护家人的员工。

examples.en: The new policy flexibilizes the approval process so small purchases move faster.
examples.zh: 新政策让审批流程更灵活，使小额采购推进更快。

examples.en: Heat often flexibilizes plastic, making it easier to shape.
examples.zh: 加热常会让塑料变软、变得更有弹性，从而更容易成型。

extraExplanation: “flexibilize”在日常英语里不算常见，尤其在口语中更常说：make something flexible / increase flexibility / make the schedule more flexible。
它常见于商业、政策或管理语境，强调“提高适应变化的能力”，语气比“flexible”更正式、更抽象。
拼写与动词后缀 -ize（使……化/使成为……）有关，含义类似于 modernize（使现代化）、legalize（使合法化）。

summary.en: “Flexibilizing” means making something less rigid and more adaptable, often in policies, schedules, or systems.
summary.zh: “flexibilizing”表示让某事物不那么僵硬、变得更有弹性与适应性，常用于政策、时间安排或制度等语境。

definition.en: making something more flexible or adaptable; reducing rigid rules, structures, or limits
definition.zh: 使某事物更有弹性/更灵活；降低僵硬的规则、结构或限制

examples.en: The company is flexibilizing work schedules to support parents and caregivers.
examples.zh: 公司正在让工作时间安排更灵活，以支持有孩子或需要照护家人的员工。

examples.en: Some countries are flexibilizing labor laws to encourage hiring.
examples.zh: 一些国家正在放宽（使更灵活）劳动法规，以鼓励雇佣。

examples.en: The teacher is flexibilizing the grading policy for students who were sick.
examples.zh: 老师正在对生病的学生放宽评分政策。

definition.en: (grammar/linguistics, less common) changing a word or form so it can be used in a wider range of situations
definition.zh: （语法/语言学，较少见）使某个词或形式能在更多语境中使用的变化/调整

examples.en: The writer is flexibilizing the expression so it works in both formal and casual contexts.
examples.zh: 作者在调整这个表达方式，让它在正式与非正式语境都适用。

extraExplanation: “flexibilizing”来自动词“flexibilize（使灵活化）”。在日常英语里更常见的说法是：make (something) more flexible / increase flexibility / loosen rules。
它常见于商业、人力资源、公共政策、经济学等语境（例如：flexibilizing labor markets/work arrangements），语气偏正式、书面。

summary.en: Flexibility means the ability to bend easily or adapt; it can also mean having room for choice in schedules, rules, or systems.
summary.zh: Flexibility 指“柔韧性/灵活性、适应变化的能力”，也可指日程、规则或制度上的“弹性与可变通空间”。

definition.en: (Correct spelling: flexibility) The ability to bend easily or change without breaking; the ability to adapt to new conditions or plans.
definition.zh: （正确拼写：flexibility）柔韧性；灵活性；适应变化的能力。

examples.en: Yoga helps improve flexibility in your hips and shoulders.
examples.zh: 瑜伽有助于提升髋部和肩部的柔韧性。

examples.en: We need flexibility in our schedule because the weather can change quickly.
examples.zh: 我们的日程需要有灵活性，因为天气可能很快变化。

definition.en: The quality of having many possible choices or ways of doing something (often in work, rules, or systems).
definition.zh: （常指工作、规则或制度）弹性；可选择空间；可变通的程度。

examples.en: This job offers flexibility, like working from home two days a week.
examples.zh: 这份工作很有弹性，比如每周有两天可以在家办公。

examples.en: The new policy gives teachers more flexibility in how they design lessons.
examples.zh: 新政策让老师在设计课程方式上有更大的灵活空间。

extraExplanation: 你输入的“flexibilty”少了一个字母“i”。正确拼写是“flexibility”。
词根提示：flex- 表示“弯曲”（如 flex = 弯曲/展示肌肉），-ibility 表示“……的能力”。

summary.en: Flexible means (1) able to bend without breaking, or (2) able to adapt or change easily (plans, rules, people).
summary.zh: Flexible 表示（1）柔韧可弯曲；或（2）做事/安排/规则灵活、能变通、能适应变化。

definition.en: Able to bend easily without breaking; not stiff.
definition.zh: （材料）柔韧的；可弯曲而不易断的；不僵硬的。

examples.en: This plastic ruler is flexible, so it won’t snap easily.
examples.zh: 这把塑料尺很柔韧，所以不容易折断。

examples.en: Yoga helps keep your body flexible.
examples.zh: 瑜伽有助于让身体更柔软灵活。

definition.en: Able to change or adapt to new conditions; not fixed or strict.
definition.zh: （安排/规则/计划）灵活的；可调整的；不死板的。

examples.en: My work schedule is flexible, so I can start earlier or later.
examples.zh: 我的工作时间很灵活，所以我可以早点或晚点开始。

examples.en: We need a flexible plan in case the weather changes.
examples.zh: 我们需要一个灵活的计划，以防天气变化。

examples.en: She’s flexible about where we eat.
examples.zh: 她对去哪儿吃饭很随和/不挑剔。

extraExplanation: “Flexible”常见两大用法：①指“可弯曲的”（偏物理性质）；②指“可变通的/能适应的”（偏性格、规则或安排）。学习时可以用“flex（弯曲/伸展）”来记忆：能弯、能伸，就更“灵活”。
在职场语境里，flexible常带正面含义，如“flexible hours（弹性工时）”“flexible policy（灵活政策）”。但如果想表达“没有原则、随便改”，更自然的说法是“inconsistent”或“unreliable”，避免误用。

summary.en: Flexibleness means the quality of being flexible (able to bend or adapt easily). It is less common than “flexibility.”
summary.zh: flexibleness 表示“灵活/柔韧”的性质（能弯曲或适应变化），但不如 flexibility 常用自然。

definition.en: The quality of being able to bend, change, or adapt easily; flexibility.
definition.zh: 能轻松弯曲、改变或适应的性质；灵活性。

examples.en: Yoga can improve the flexibleness of your hips and shoulders.
examples.zh: 瑜伽可以提高你髋部和肩部的柔韧性。

examples.en: We need flexibleness in our schedule because the weather may change.
examples.zh: 我们需要让日程更有弹性，因为天气可能会变化。

extraExplanation: “flexibleness”是可用但较少见的名词形式；更常见、更自然的说法是“flexibility”。在学术写作、工作场景或日常表达中，通常优先用“flexibility”。

summary.en: “Flexibly” means “in an adaptable way,” and sometimes “in a physically bendable way.”
summary.zh: “flexibly”表示“灵活地、能变通地”，有时也指“柔韧地、可弯曲地”。

definition.en: In a way that can change easily to fit new situations or needs; with adaptability.
definition.zh: 灵活地；有弹性地（能根据新情况或需要调整）。

examples.en: We need to schedule meetings flexibly because everyone is in different time zones.
examples.zh: 因为大家在不同的时区，我们需要灵活地安排会议。

examples.en: She works flexibly, sometimes from home and sometimes from the office.
examples.zh: 她的工作方式很灵活，有时在家办公，有时去办公室。

definition.en: In a way that is able to bend without breaking; with physical flexibility.
definition.zh: 柔韧地；可弯曲而不易折断地（指身体或材料的弹性）。

examples.en: The yoga instructor showed how to move flexibly and safely.
examples.zh: 瑜伽老师示范了如何柔韧而安全地动作。

examples.en: This plastic tube can flexibly bend around corners.
examples.zh: 这种塑料管可以柔韧地绕过拐角。

extraExplanation: “flexibly”来自“flex”（弯曲）这一词根，所以既可以指“思维/安排上的灵活”，也可以指“身体或材料的柔韧”。日常职场语境中更常用第一种（可调整、可变通）。
常见搭配：work flexibly（灵活工作）、respond flexibly（灵活应对）、arrange/schedule flexibly（灵活安排）。相近表达：adaptably（适应性地）、with flexibility（以灵活的方式）。

summary.en: Flexile means “easily bent; flexible,” and is a rarer, more literary alternative to flexible. It can also describe a person or mind that adapts easily.
summary.zh: flexile 意为“易弯曲的、柔韧的”，是 flexible 的较少见、较书面的替代说法；也可指人或思维“适应性强、能变通”。

definition.en: Easily bent; flexible; able to change shape without breaking.
definition.zh: 易弯曲的；柔韧的；能在不折断的情况下改变形状的。

examples.en: The flexile branches moved smoothly in the wind.
examples.zh: 这些柔韧的树枝在风中顺畅地摆动。

examples.en: Choose a flexile material if you need the cable to bend around corners.
examples.zh: 如果你需要电缆绕过拐角，就选用柔韧的材料。

definition.en: (Figurative, less common) Able to adapt easily; open to change.
definition.zh: （比喻义，较少见）适应性强的；容易变通的。

examples.en: She has a flexile mindset and can adjust when plans change.
examples.zh: 她的思维很灵活，计划变化时也能及时调整。

extraExplanation: “flexile”是比较少见、偏书面/文学的词，更常用的对应词是“flexible”。在日常英语里，描述“柔韧/可弯曲”几乎都会用“flexible”。
词源上与拉丁语词根 *flex-*（弯曲）相关，也同一家族词包括：*flex*（弯曲/展示肌肉）、*reflex*（反射/反射动作）、*inflexible*（不灵活的）。

summary.en: “Flexility” is usually a misspelling of “flexibility,” meaning physical bendability or the ability to adapt easily.
summary.zh: “flexility” 通常是 “flexibility” 的拼写错误，意思是身体/材料的柔韧性或做事的灵活变通能力。

definition.en: (Commonly spelled **flexibility**) the ability to bend easily without breaking; the quality of being flexible in body or material.
definition.zh: （常见拼写为 **flexibility**）可轻易弯曲而不折断的能力；身体或材料的柔韧性。

examples.en: Yoga helps improve your flexibility.
examples.zh: 瑜伽有助于提升你的柔韧性。

examples.en: This plastic has enough flexibility to bend without snapping.
examples.zh: 这种塑料柔韧性够强，弯曲也不会断裂。

definition.en: The ability to adapt or change plans easily; willingness to be open to different options.
definition.zh: 随机应变的能力；在计划或做法上能灵活调整、愿意接受不同选择。

examples.en: We need flexibility because the schedule may change.
examples.zh: 我们需要灵活性，因为日程可能会变。

examples.en: Her flexibility at work makes teamwork easier.
examples.zh: 她在工作中的灵活性让团队合作更顺畅。

extraExplanation: 你输入的 **flexility** 通常被认为是拼写错误；标准拼写是 **flexibility**。词根来自 **flex-**（弯曲），常见相关词有 **flexible**（灵活的、柔软的）。

summary.en: “Flexing” means bending/tensing a body part, or (in slang) showing off to impress others.
summary.zh: “flexing”既可指屈伸/绷紧身体部位，也可作俚语指“炫耀、秀一秀”。

definition.en: Bending, tightening, or moving a body part (especially a muscle or joint).
definition.zh: 弯曲、绷紧或活动身体部位（尤指肌肉或关节）。

examples.en: He was flexing his arm to show how strong he is.
examples.zh: 他绷紧手臂，展示自己有多强壮。

examples.en: Try flexing your fingers before you start typing.
examples.zh: 打字前试着活动一下手指。

definition.en: (Slang) Showing off; trying to impress others by displaying money, status, skills, or looks.
definition.zh: （俚语）炫耀；通过展示金钱、地位、能力或外表来让别人刮目相看。

examples.en: He’s flexing with his new watch on social media.
examples.zh: 他在社交媒体上晒新表炫耀。

examples.en: No need to flex—just do your best.
examples.zh: 没必要炫耀——尽力就好。

extraExplanation: “flex”原意是“弯曲/屈伸”，比如 flex your knees（屈膝）。后来在流行文化与网络语境中引申为“展示实力/炫耀”，常见于口语与社交媒体。
俚语用法有时带调侃或负面评价（暗示夸耀），但也可能是轻松中性的自夸。可根据语气与场合判断。

summary.en: Flexion means bending (especially of a joint) and, less commonly, a grammatical change in word form (inflection).
summary.zh: flexion主要指（关节等的）屈曲/弯曲；较少见时也指语法上的词形变化（inflection）。

definition.en: A bending or curving movement, especially of a joint; the act of bending (the opposite of extension).
definition.zh: 屈曲；弯曲动作（尤指关节的弯曲；与伸展 extension 相对）。

examples.en: Flexion of the knee happens when you bend your leg.
examples.zh: 膝关节屈曲就是把腿弯起来。

examples.en: The therapist measured her shoulder flexion after the injury.
examples.zh: 治疗师在受伤后测量了她的肩关节屈曲度。

definition.en: In grammar, a change in the form of a word to show meaning such as tense, number, case, or comparison (also called inflection).
definition.zh: （语法）词形变化：通过改变词的形式来表达时态、数、格或比较级等意义（也叫 inflection）。

examples.en: In English, “walk” → “walked” is a flexion that shows past tense.
examples.zh: 在英语里，“walk”变成“walked”就是表示过去时的词形变化。

examples.en: Some languages use many flexions to show case and gender.
examples.zh: 有些语言会用很多词形变化来表示格和性别。

extraExplanation: “flexion”在现代英语里更常见于医学/运动科学语境（关节活动度 ROM）。在语言学/语法里，更常用的词是“inflection（词形变化）”。
词源上与拉丁语“flex-（弯曲）”有关，因此在不同领域都保留了“变化/弯曲”的核心概念。

summary.en: Flexional means “inflectional”: related to changing word forms to express grammar (tense, number, etc.).
summary.zh: flexional 意为“屈折的/屈折变化相关的”：指通过改变词形来表达语法信息（如时态、数等）。

definition.en: Relating to changes in the form of a word (inflection) to show grammar, such as tense, number, case, or comparison.
definition.zh: （语言学）与“屈折变化”有关的；指通过改变词形来表达语法信息，如时态、数、格或比较级等。

examples.en: English has relatively few flexional endings compared with Spanish.
examples.zh: 与西班牙语相比，英语的屈折词尾相对较少。

examples.en: The -s in “cats” is a flexional marker for plural number.
examples.zh: “cats”里的 -s 是表示复数的屈折标记。

extraExplanation: “flexional”主要用于语言学（linguistics）语境，和“inflectional”意思非常接近；在现代教材和论文里，“inflectional”更常见。
屈折（inflection）与派生（derivation）不同：屈折通常不改变词类（如 walk→walked），派生常会改变词类或核心意义（如 happy→happiness）。
常见的屈折例子：名词复数 -s（book→books）、动词过去式 -ed（work→worked）、第三人称单数 -s（run→runs）、形容词比较级 -er/-est（small→smaller→smallest）。

summary.en: “Flexionless” means “inflectionless”—not using word-form changes to mark grammar.
summary.zh: “flexionless”意为“无屈折变化的（inflectionless）”，不靠词形变化来表达语法信息。

definition.en: Without inflection (no changes in word form to show tense, number, case, etc.).
definition.zh: 无屈折变化的；不通过词形变化来表达时态、数、格等语法信息的。

examples.en: In a flexionless language, word order often carries more meaning than word endings.
examples.zh: 在无屈折变化的语言中，词序往往比词尾变化承载更多意义。

examples.en: Some learners find flexionless grammar easier at first because there are fewer endings to memorize.
examples.zh: 一些学习者起初觉得无屈折变化的语法更容易，因为需要记的词尾变化更少。

extraExplanation: “flexionless”是语言学里比较少见的词，更常见的近义表达是“inflectionless”。“inflection/inflectional endings”指像英语第三人称单数 -s、过去式 -ed、名词复数 -s 这类词形变化。
不要把“inflectionless（无屈折）”和“toneless（无声调）”或“stressless（无重音）”混淆：前者讨论的是语法形式（词形变化），后者讨论的是语音特征。

summary.en: “Flexions” means the inflected forms of a word, or the system of grammatical word-ending changes.
summary.zh: “flexions”指词的屈折形式，或指语言中用词形变化（多为词尾变化）表达语法的体系。

definition.en: Inflected forms of a word (changes in form to show tense, number, case, etc.).
definition.zh: 词的屈折形式（通过形式变化来表示时态、单复数、格等）。

examples.en: The verb “walk” has flexions like “walks,” “walked,” and “walking.”
examples.zh: 动词 walk 有一些屈折形式，如 walks、walked、walking。

examples.en: In English, flexions are usually shown with endings like -s or -ed.
examples.zh: 在英语里，屈折通常通过词尾变化来体现，比如 -s 或 -ed。

definition.en: The act or system of inflection in a language; word-ending changes used by grammar.
definition.zh: 屈折变化这一行为或体系；语言中用于语法表达的词尾变化。

examples.en: Compared with Latin, English has fewer flexions.
examples.zh: 和拉丁语相比，英语的屈折变化更少。

examples.en: Old English used more flexions to show grammatical relationships.
examples.zh: 古英语使用更多屈折变化来表达语法关系。

extraExplanation: “flexion(s)” 在语言学里常写作 inflection(s)。英式英语中 inflexion 也存在，但 inflection 更常见。
英语的屈折变化相对“少”，常见例子包括：名词复数 -s（cats）、第三人称单数 -s（she runs）、过去式 -ed（played）、比较级/最高级 -er/-est（faster/fastest）。
在一些语言（如俄语、德语、拉丁语）中，屈折变化更多、更复杂，常用来表达“格”（主格、宾格等）以及更细的语法信息。

summary.en: A flexitarian is someone who is mostly vegetarian but occasionally eats meat or fish; it can also describe that diet style.
summary.zh: flexitarian 指主要吃素但偶尔吃肉或鱼的人，也可形容这种“弹性素食”的饮食方式。

definition.en: A person who mainly eats a vegetarian diet but sometimes eats meat or fish.
definition.zh: （主要吃素、但偶尔吃肉或鱼的）弹性素食者；半素食者。

examples.en: She’s a flexitarian, so she usually chooses vegetarian meals but eats chicken sometimes.
examples.zh: 她是弹性素食者，所以通常吃素，但有时会吃鸡肉。

examples.en: More restaurants now offer options for vegans, vegetarians, and flexitarians.
examples.zh: 现在越来越多餐厅为纯素者、素食者和弹性素食者提供选择。

definition.en: Related to a mostly vegetarian eating style that allows occasional meat or fish.
definition.zh: 指一种以素食为主、允许偶尔吃肉或鱼的饮食方式的。

examples.en: He follows a flexitarian diet to eat healthier without giving up meat entirely.
examples.zh: 他采取弹性素食饮食，以更健康为目标，但不完全放弃吃肉。

examples.en: A flexitarian approach can make it easier to eat more plant-based foods.
examples.zh: 弹性素食的做法能让人更容易增加植物性食物的比例。

extraExplanation: “flexitarian”由“flexible（灵活的）+ vegetarian（素食者）”组合而来，强调饮食选择更有弹性：大多数时候以植物性食物为主，但不把自己严格限制为完全不吃肉。
在英语语境中，它常与“plant-based（以植物为主）”“reduce meat（减少吃肉）”等表达一起出现，属于比较中性、生活方式导向的词。

summary.en: Flexitime is a flexible working-hours system that lets people choose their start and finish times within set rules.
summary.zh: Flexitime 指一种弹性工时制度，允许员工在规定范围内灵活选择上下班时间。

definition.en: A work arrangement where employees can choose (within limits) when they start and finish work, as long as they work the required hours and are present during core hours if required.
definition.zh: 一种弹性工时制度：员工可在一定范围内选择上下班时间；只要完成规定工时，并在需要时于“核心工作时间”在岗即可。

examples.en: Our office offers flexitime, so I start at 7:30 and leave at 3:30.
examples.zh: 我们办公室实行弹性工时，所以我7:30上班、3:30下班。

examples.en: With flexitime, parents can adjust their schedules around school drop-off.
examples.zh: 有了弹性工时，家长可以把工作时间调整到接送孩子上学的安排周围。

examples.en: Even on flexitime, everyone must be available from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m.
examples.zh: 即使是弹性工时，大家也必须在上午10点到下午3点之间保持可联系、可到岗。

extraExplanation: “flexitime”在英式英语中非常常见；美式英语里也会用，但更常见的说法包括“flex time”或“flexible schedule”。
它通常与“core hours（核心工作时间）”“compressed workweek（压缩工作周，如四天工作制）”“remote/hybrid work（远程/混合办公）”一起出现，但概念不同：flexitime强调的是“可弹性选择上下班时间”。

summary.en: “Flexity” means flexibility or adaptability, but it’s uncommon; “flexibility” is the standard word.
summary.zh: “flexity”意为“柔韧性/灵活性”，但较少见；标准常用词是“flexibility”。

definition.en: flexibility; the quality of being able to bend easily or adapt to change
definition.zh: 柔韧性；灵活性（指容易弯曲或能适应变化的特质）

examples.en: Yoga can improve your body’s flexity and balance.
examples.zh: 瑜伽可以提升你身体的柔韧性和平衡感。

examples.en: The team’s flexity helped them adjust to last-minute changes.
examples.zh: 团队的灵活性帮助他们适应了临时变化。

extraExplanation: “flexity”在现代英语中很少见；更常用、也更自然的词是“flexibility”。在正式写作或考试中，建议优先使用“flexibility”，以避免被当作拼写错误。
词源上与“flex-”（弯曲）相关，意义通常指“可弯曲/可适应”。你也可能是在找“flexibility”（更常见）或“flexity”（较少用的变体/造词）。

summary.en: Flexive usually means “inflectional,” describing grammar shown by changing word forms; it can also (rarely) mean “flexible.”
summary.zh: flexive 通常指“屈折的/词形变化的”（通过改变词形表达语法）；较少见时也可指“可弯曲的/柔韧的”。

definition.en: (Linguistics) relating to inflection (changes in word form to show grammar, such as tense, number, or case).
definition.zh: （语言学）与“屈折/词形变化”有关的；指通过词形变化表达语法信息（如时态、数、格）的。

examples.en: English has some flexive endings, like -s in cats and -ed in walked.
examples.zh: 英语有一些屈折词尾，比如 cats 里的 -s 和 walked 里的 -ed。

examples.en: Latin is often described as a flexive language because nouns and verbs change form a lot.
examples.zh: 拉丁语常被描述为屈折语，因为名词和动词的词形变化很多。

definition.en: (General, rare) able to bend; flexible.
definition.zh: （一般用法，较少见）可弯曲的；柔韧的。

examples.en: The flexive stem moved slightly under pressure.
examples.zh: 这个可弯曲的茎在压力下微微移动。

extraExplanation: “flexive”在现代英语里不算常用，更常见的说法是 inflectional（屈折的/词形变化的）或 inflected（发生屈折变化的）。
语言类型里常提到：inflectional/flexive language（屈折语，如拉丁语、俄语）与 isolating（孤立语，如汉语）和 agglutinative（黏着语，如土耳其语、日语）作对比。

summary.en: “Flexo” usually means flexographic printing, widely used for packaging.
summary.zh: “flexo”通常指柔版印刷（柔印），广泛用于包装印刷。

definition.en: Flexographic printing; the flexography process used to print packaging (labels, plastic films, cartons, etc.).
definition.zh: 柔版印刷；一种常用于包装（标签、塑料薄膜、纸盒等）的印刷工艺。

examples.en: The company switched to flexo for printing food packaging.
examples.zh: 公司改用柔版印刷来印食品包装。

examples.en: Flexo is common for labels and plastic film.
examples.zh: 柔版印刷常用于标签和塑料薄膜。

definition.en: Relating to flexographic printing.
definition.zh: 与柔版印刷有关的；柔版印刷的。

examples.en: We need flexo inks that dry quickly.
examples.zh: 我们需要干得快的柔版印刷油墨。

examples.en: They run a flexo press for large orders.
examples.zh: 他们用柔版印刷机处理大批量订单。

extraExplanation: “flexo”是“flexography / flexographic”的常见简称，来自“flexible（柔性的）”，因为这种工艺使用柔性的印版（多为橡胶或光聚合物）。
在流行文化中，“Flexo”也可能指动画剧《Futurama（飞出个未来）》里的机器人角色名；这种用法通常是专有名词，需要结合上下文判断。

summary.en: Flexographic means “having to do with flexography,” a common packaging printing method using flexible plates.
summary.zh: flexographic 指“与柔版印刷有关的”，柔版印刷是一种常见的包装印刷方式，使用柔性印版。

definition.en: Related to flexography: a printing method that uses flexible relief plates and quick‑drying inks, often for packaging materials like labels, plastic film, and cardboard.
definition.zh: 与柔版印刷有关的：一种使用柔性凸版印版与快干油墨的印刷方式，常用于包装材料，如标签、塑料薄膜和纸板。

examples.en: Flexographic printing is widely used for food packaging because it works well on plastic films.
examples.zh: 柔版印刷广泛用于食品包装，因为它很适合在塑料薄膜上印刷。

examples.en: The company invested in a new flexographic press to improve label quality.
examples.zh: 公司投资了一台新的柔版印刷机来提升标签质量。

extraExplanation: “flexographic”来自“flexography”（柔版印刷）。这种工艺的特点是印版柔软可弯曲（flexible plate），适合在不平整或可卷曲的材料上高速印刷，因此在包装行业非常常见。日常交流里更常见的是名词“flexography”或短语“flexographic printing/press”。

summary.en: Flexographically means “using or relating to flexography,” a common printing method for packaging and labels.
summary.zh: flexographically 指“以柔版印刷的方式；与柔版印刷有关”，常用于包装与标签印刷语境。

definition.en: In a way that relates to flexography (a rotary printing method that uses flexible relief plates), especially in packaging and label printing.
definition.zh: 以柔版印刷（使用柔性凸版的轮转印刷方式）的方式；尤指用于包装与标签印刷。

examples.en: The company prints snack packages flexographically to reduce costs and speed up production.
examples.zh: 这家公司用柔版印刷来印零食包装，以降低成本并加快生产。

examples.en: This ink is designed to dry quickly when used flexographically on plastic film.
examples.zh: 这种油墨适合在塑料薄膜上进行柔版印刷时快速干燥。

extraExplanation: “flexographically”来自“flexography（柔版印刷）+ -ally（副词后缀）”。在英语里，它多见于印刷、包装、材料与工艺的技术语境中。
柔版印刷常用于：食品包装、纸箱、标签、塑料薄膜等；特点通常是速度快、适合大批量连续印刷，但对网纹辊、油墨与基材匹配要求较高。

summary.en: Flexography is a common packaging-printing method that uses flexible raised plates.
summary.zh: Flexography 指常见的包装印刷工艺：用柔软凸版印版进行印刷。

definition.en: A printing process that uses flexible raised plates (often rubber or photopolymer) to print on materials like packaging, labels, plastic film, and cardboard, usually with fast-drying inks.
definition.zh: 柔版印刷（凸版印刷的一种）：使用柔软的凸版印版（常为橡胶或感光树脂）在包装、标签、塑料薄膜、纸板等材料上印刷，通常配合快干油墨。

examples.en: Most snack bags are printed using flexography because it works well on plastic film.
examples.zh: 很多零食包装袋用柔版印刷，因为它很适合在塑料薄膜上印刷。

examples.en: The company switched to flexography to produce labels faster and at lower cost.
examples.zh: 这家公司改用柔版印刷，以更快、更低成本地生产标签。

extraExplanation: 柔版印刷常用于“包装印刷”领域，因为它能在不太平整、可弯曲的材料（如薄膜、瓦楞纸板）上稳定印刷。
它常见的搭配词包括：flexographic printing（柔版印刷）、flexo press（柔印机/柔版印刷机）、flexo plate（柔版印版）、water-based inks（水性油墨）。
词源上，flexography 来自 flexo-（表示“柔性的”）+ -graphy（表示“书写/印刷的过程”）。

summary.en: “Flexography-related” means connected with flexographic printing, especially in packaging and labels.
summary.zh: “flexography-related”指与柔版印刷相关，常用于包装与标签印刷语境。

definition.en: connected with or involving flexography (a printing method that uses flexible relief plates, often for packaging).
definition.zh: 与柔版印刷有关的；涉及柔版印刷的（柔版印刷是一种使用柔性凸版印版的印刷方式，常用于包装印刷）。

examples.en: She has five years of flexography-related experience in packaging printing.
examples.zh: 她在包装印刷领域有五年的柔版印刷相关经验。

examples.en: We attended a flexography-related workshop on ink viscosity and plate mounting.
examples.zh: 我们参加了一场与柔版印刷相关的研讨会，主题是油墨黏度和版材装贴。

examples.en: The factory is hiring flexography-related technicians for the new label line.
examples.zh: 工厂正在为新的标签产线招聘柔版印刷相关技术人员。

extraExplanation: “flexography-related”是由“flexography（柔版印刷）+ related（相关的）”组成的复合形容词，常见于招聘信息、技术文档和培训课程标题中。
柔版印刷在北美尤其常用于食品包装、瓦楞纸箱、塑料薄膜、胶带与标签等领域；因此你会常看到“flexography-related skills / jobs / training / issues”等搭配。

summary.en: A flexor is a muscle that bends a joint.
summary.zh: flexor 指“屈肌”，即让关节弯曲的肌肉。

definition.en: A muscle that bends a joint (for example, bending your elbow or curling your fingers).
definition.zh: 屈肌；使关节弯曲的肌肉（例如弯曲手肘或蜷曲手指）。

examples.en: The biceps is a flexor that helps bend the elbow.
examples.zh: 肱二头肌是一块屈肌，帮助弯曲手肘。

examples.en: Rock climbers often train their finger flexors to improve grip strength.
examples.zh: 攀岩者常训练手指屈肌来提升握力。

extraExplanation: 在解剖学里，flexor 常和 extensor（伸肌）成对出现：flexor 负责“屈/弯”，extensor 负责“伸/直”。
词源上，flexor 来自拉丁语词根 flex-，表示“弯曲”（同源词如 flexible “灵活的”、flex “弯曲/展示肌肉”）。在医学或运动训练语境中，这个词更常见。

summary.en: “Flexors” are muscles that bend a joint (plural of “flexor”).
summary.zh: “flexors”指屈肌：使关节弯曲的肌肉（为“flexor”的复数）。

definition.en: Muscles that bend a joint, decreasing the angle between two bones (the opposite of extensors).
definition.zh: 屈肌：使关节弯曲、让两块骨头之间的夹角变小的肌肉（与伸肌相对）。

examples.en: Strong wrist flexors help you grip a racket firmly.
examples.zh: 强壮的手腕屈肌能帮助你更稳地握住球拍。

examples.en: After the workout, he stretched his hip flexors to reduce tightness.
examples.zh: 训练后，他拉伸髋屈肌来缓解紧绷。

extraExplanation: “flexors”是“flexor”的复数。日常健身与康复中最常见的搭配包括：hip flexors（髋屈肌群）、finger flexors（手指屈肌）、wrist flexors（腕屈肌）。
在解剖学与运动语境里，人们常用“flexors vs. extensors（屈肌与伸肌）”来描述一组拮抗肌：一组负责弯曲，另一组负责伸直。训练中强调两者平衡，有助于减少受伤风险。

summary.en: Flextime is a flexible work-hours system where you can choose your start and end times within rules.
summary.zh: Flextime 指在规则范围内可自由选择上下班时间的弹性工时制度。

definition.en: A work schedule that lets employees choose (within limits) when they start and finish work, often while still working a required number of hours.
definition.zh: （在一定限制内）员工可自行选择上下班时间的弹性工时制度，通常仍需完成规定工时。

examples.en: Our company offers flextime, so I start at 7 a.m. and leave early.
examples.zh: 我们公司提供弹性工时，所以我早上7点上班，早些下班。

examples.en: With flextime, parents can adjust their hours to pick up their kids from school.
examples.zh: 有了弹性工时，家长可以调整工作时间去接孩子放学。

extraExplanation: “flextime”主要用于职场语境，常见于员工福利与人力资源制度描述。它通常意味着有一个“核心工作时间”（core hours），例如10点到3点必须在岗，其余时间可弹性安排。
相关词汇：flexible schedule（弹性排班/弹性日程）、flex hours（弹性工时）、compressed workweek（压缩工作周，如四天上完五天工时）、remote work / telecommuting（远程办公）。

summary.en: Flexuose means “flexuous”: gently winding or full of smooth curves (rare, literary).
summary.zh: flexuose 意为“flexuous”：柔和地蜿蜒、曲折起伏的（较罕见、偏文学用法）。

definition.en: (Rare) Having many gentle bends or curves; winding in a smooth, wave-like way.
definition.zh: （罕见）多弯曲的；蜿蜒起伏的；呈柔和波浪状弯曲的。

examples.en: A flexuose path led through the garden, curving between the trees.
examples.zh: 一条蜿蜒起伏的小路穿过花园，在树间弯弯绕绕。

examples.en: The artist painted a flexuose line to suggest the movement of water.
examples.zh: 画家画出一条波浪般弯曲的线，来表现水流的动感。

extraExplanation: “flexuose”是较少见的拼写形式，更常见的是“flexuous”。
词源上与拉丁语 *flectere*（弯曲、转向）相关，因此常用于较文学或描述性很强的语境，来强调“柔和、连续的弯曲”，而不是“折角”或“急转弯”。
近义词提示：*winding*（蜿蜒的，最常用、口语也自然）、*curving*（弯曲的，中性）、*sinuous*（蜿蜒而优雅的，较文学）。

summary.en: “Flexuosely” means “in a winding or smoothly curving way.”
summary.zh: “flexuosely”表示“蜿蜒地、曲线地（柔和弯曲地）”。

definition.en: In a winding, curving, or smoothly bending way; not straight.
definition.zh: 以蜿蜒、弯曲或柔和弯折的方式；不笔直地。

examples.en: The river moved flexuosely through the valley.
examples.zh: 河流在山谷中蜿蜒流淌。

examples.en: A flexuosely shaped branch reached over the path.
examples.zh: 一根弯弯曲曲的树枝伸到小路上方。

examples.en: The dancer’s arms flowed flexuosely from one pose to the next.
examples.zh: 舞者的手臂从一个姿势到下一个姿势柔和地曲线流动。

extraExplanation: “flexuosely”比较少见、偏书面/文学用语，日常英语更常用：“in a winding way / sinuously / in curves”。
词源上与拉丁语“flex-”（弯曲）有关，同词根常见词有：flex（弯曲、屈伸）、flexible（灵活的、可弯曲的）。
常见搭配场景：描述河流、道路、藤蔓、枝条的走向，或舞蹈/动作的“流线感”。注意：它通常形容“线条/路径/动作”的弯曲，而不是人的性格。

summary.en: Flexuoseness means the quality of being winding or curving back and forth (more commonly spelled flexuousness).
summary.zh: flexuoseness 指“蜿蜒曲折”的性质（更常见拼写为 flexuousness）。

definition.en: the quality of being winding or curving back and forth; sinuosity
definition.zh: 蜿蜒曲折的性质；弯弯曲曲（的程度）

examples.en: The flexuoseness of the river makes the boat trip much longer than the straight-line distance.
examples.zh: 河流的蜿蜒曲折让船程比直线距离长得多。

examples.en: Writers sometimes describe a mountain road’s flexuoseness to create a vivid picture.
examples.zh: 作家有时会用“蜿蜒曲折”来描写山路，使画面更生动。

extraExplanation: “flexuoseness”非常少见，更常见的拼写是“flexuousness”，意思相同。
词根来自拉丁语“flexus”（弯曲）与“-ous”（……的），“flexuous”常用于文学或较正式的描写，形容道路、河流、线条、叙事结构等“曲折蜿蜒”。

summary.en: “Flexuosities” means winding curves or bends, and can also mean figurative indirectness.
summary.zh: “flexuosities”指蜿蜒的曲折，也可比喻说话或做事的拐弯抹角。

definition.en: (plural noun) Winding curves or bends; the quality of being wavy or sinuous (often in a path, line, river, or handwriting).
definition.zh: （复数名词）弯弯曲曲的曲折；蜿蜒起伏的特性（常指道路、线条、河流或笔迹的曲线感）。

examples.en: The river’s flexuosities made the journey much longer than it looked on the map.
examples.zh: 这条河的蜿蜒曲折让旅程比地图上看起来长得多。

examples.en: She traced the flexuosities of the coastline with her finger.
examples.zh: 她用手指沿着海岸线的曲折蜿蜒慢慢描画。

definition.en: (figurative, plural noun) Indirect or twisting ways of speaking or acting; evasive complexity.
definition.zh: （比喻，复数名词）说话或做事的拐弯抹角、迂回曲折；闪烁其词的复杂性。

examples.en: He answered with flexuosities instead of giving a clear yes or no.
examples.zh: 他没有明确回答是或不是，而是拐弯抹角地回应。

examples.en: The debate was full of rhetorical flexuosities that confused the audience.
examples.zh: 这场辩论充满修辞上的迂回曲折，让观众感到困惑。

extraExplanation: “flexuosities”是“flexuosity”的复数形式，属于比较书面、较少见的词，常用于描写自然景观（河流、道路、山脊、海岸线）的“蜿蜒”，也可用于批评言语或论证的“曲折绕弯”。
词源上与拉丁语词根有关：flex-（弯曲）+ -osity（性质/状态）。同源常见词有“flex”（弯曲、灵活）和“flexible”（灵活的）。

summary.en: Flexuosity means the quality of being winding or curved, and can also mean figurative complexity or indirectness.
summary.zh: flexuosity 指“弯曲蜿蜒”的特性，也可比喻为“复杂迂回、不直接”。

definition.en: A bend or curve; a winding shape or movement rather than being straight.
definition.zh: 弯曲；曲折；（形状或路线）不是直线而是蜿蜒的样子。

examples.en: The river’s flexuosity makes the boat ride slower but more scenic.
examples.zh: 河流的曲折让乘船变慢，但风景更美。

examples.en: Engineers studied the flexuosity of the road before redesigning the intersection.
examples.zh: 工程师在重新设计路口前研究了道路的弯曲程度。

definition.en: Figuratively, complexity or indirectness in a plan, argument, or way of speaking.
definition.zh: （比喻）计划、论证或表达方式的复杂与迂回；不直截了当。

examples.en: His explanation had so much flexuosity that I lost the main point.
examples.zh: 他的解释太迂回复杂，我都抓不住重点了。

examples.en: The flexuosity of the plot keeps readers guessing.
examples.zh: 情节的曲折复杂让读者一直猜个不停。

extraExplanation: 这个词比较书面、偏学术，常见于地理（河道蜿蜒）、工程（道路曲线）、医学（管道/血管弯曲）、以及文学批评（叙事“曲折”）等语境。日常英语里更常用 winding, curving, twists and turns, complexity 等表达。
词源上与拉丁语 flexus（“弯曲”）相关，同根常见词包括 flexible（灵活的）、to flex（使弯曲/展示肌肉）。

summary.en: Flexuoso is not standard English; the closest English word is flexuous, meaning gently winding or sinuous.
summary.zh: Flexuoso 不是标准英语；最接近的英语词是 flexuous，意思是“蜿蜒的、弯曲迂回的”。

definition.en: (Not common in modern English) Winding or curving in a gentle, wave-like way; sinuous.
definition.zh: （现代英语中不常见）弯弯曲曲的；呈波浪状蜿蜒的；迂回的。

examples.en: A flexuous path led down to the river through the tall grass.
examples.zh: 一条蜿蜒的小路穿过高草，通向河边。

examples.en: The flexuous line of the coastline is easier to see from above.
examples.zh: 从高处更容易看出海岸线的曲折蜿蜒。

examples.en: In the poem, the flexuous movement of the snake feels calm rather than threatening.
examples.zh: 在诗中，蛇蜿蜒的动作显得平静，而非带有威胁。

extraExplanation: “flexuoso”更像是西班牙语/葡萄牙语形式；英语里更常见（但仍偏文学/正式）的对应词是“flexuous”。
词源来自拉丁语词根 flex-（“弯曲”），也出现在 flexible（灵活的）等词中。由于较少用于日常口语，更常见的替换表达有 winding、curving、meandering、sinuous。

summary.en: Flexuous means gently curved or winding, often used in literary or formal descriptions.
summary.zh: flexuous 意为“柔和弯曲、蜿蜒”，常见于较正式或文学性的描写。

definition.en: Having many gentle curves; winding rather than straight.
definition.zh: （线条、形状、路径等）弯弯曲曲的；呈柔和曲线的；蜿蜒的。

examples.en: A flexuous river wound through the valley.
examples.zh: 一条蜿蜒的河流穿过山谷。

examples.en: The artist drew a flexuous line to suggest movement.
examples.zh: 艺术家画了一条柔和弯曲的线来表现动感。

definition.en: In writing or speech, flowing in a smoothly varying way; not rigid or abrupt. (rare)
definition.zh: （文风或表达）流畅婉转的；变化自然的；不生硬突兀的。（较少见）

examples.en: Her flexuous prose shifts gently from humor to reflection.
examples.zh: 她的文笔在幽默与沉思之间自然流转。

extraExplanation: 词源提示：flexuous 来自拉丁语 flexus（“弯曲”），与 flex（弯曲、伸展）、flexible（灵活的）同源。记忆时可以把它理解为“充满弯曲的”。
使用场景：多用于较书面或文学描写（如河流、道路、藤蔓、线条、人体姿态等的“蜿蜒曲线感”）。日常口语里更常用 winding, curvy, sinuous（sinuous 更强调蛇一样的蜿蜒）。

summary.en: Flexuously means “in a winding/curving way,” literally (roads, rivers) or rarely figuratively (indirect speech/writing).
summary.zh: flexuously 表示“蜿蜒曲折地”，多用于道路、河流等的字面描写，少数情况下也可比喻说话写作迂回。

definition.en: In a winding, curving, or serpentine way; with many bends rather than straight lines.
definition.zh: 以蜿蜒、曲折、蛇行的方式；不是笔直而是多弯曲。

examples.en: The river runs flexuously through the valley.
examples.zh: 这条河蜿蜒地穿过山谷。

examples.en: A flexuously twisting path led up the hill.
examples.zh: 一条曲折盘旋的小路通向山坡上。

definition.en: In a figuratively indirect or meandering way, especially in writing or speech (rare).
definition.zh: （比喻）以迂回、绕弯、离题的方式（多用于写作或讲话，较少见）。

examples.en: He explained the plan flexuously, circling around the main point.
examples.zh: 他迂回地解释计划，总是在核心问题旁打转。

examples.en: The essay moves flexuously from one idea to another.
examples.zh: 这篇文章在不同想法之间曲折地转换。

extraExplanation: “flexuously”来自形容词“flexuous”（弯曲的、蜿蜒的），源头与拉丁语“flex-”（弯、折）有关，同一家族的常见词有“flex”（弯曲/伸展）、“flexible”（灵活的）。
它在现代日常英语中很少用；更常见的替代说法包括“windingly / in a winding way / sinuously”。其中“sinuously”更偏文学描写，语感更“流动、蛇形”。

summary.en: Flexuousness means the quality of having gentle, winding curves (literally or figuratively).
summary.zh: Flexuousness 指“蜿蜒、柔和曲折”的性质，可用于字面形状或比喻表达方式的迂回。

definition.en: The quality of being flexuous: having gentle curves or bends rather than being straight.
definition.zh: 蜿蜒性；曲折起伏的性质：形状呈柔和弯曲、非笔直。

examples.en: The river’s flexuousness makes it difficult to build a straight road along the bank.
examples.zh: 河流的蜿蜒使得沿岸修建一条笔直的道路变得困难。

examples.en: In the painting, the flexuousness of the vine leads your eyes across the canvas.
examples.zh: 在这幅画里，藤蔓的蜿蜒曲线引导你的视线穿过画布。

definition.en: (Figurative) The quality of being winding or indirect in movement, style, or reasoning.
definition.zh: （比喻）迂回性；不直截了当的行进方式、表达风格或推理路径。

examples.en: The essay’s flexuousness made the main point hard to find.
examples.zh: 这篇文章的行文迂回，让主旨很难抓住。

examples.en: He admired the flexuousness of her storytelling, even when it delayed the conclusion.
examples.zh: 他欣赏她讲故事的曲折铺陈，即使这会拖延结尾。

extraExplanation: “flexuousness”来自形容词“flexuous”（弯曲的、蜿蜒的），再加名词后缀“-ness”。它比较书面、偏文学或科学描述（如地形、河道、植物形态）。日常英语更常用“curvature”“windingness”（不常见）或直接说“how winding it is”。
和“tortuous”相比，“flexuous”通常强调“柔和的弯曲”，不一定有“艰难、扭曲、令人费解”的负面意味；“sinuous”也表示曲线优美、蜿蜒。

summary.en: Flexura means a bend or curve, especially an anatomical bend (a more Latin/technical way to say flexure).
summary.zh: flexura 指“弯曲处/屈曲”，尤指解剖学中的弯曲部位（较拉丁化、技术性的说法，接近 flexure）。

definition.en: a bend or curve; especially an anatomical bend in an organ or structure (same idea as “flexure,” but more Latin/technical in style).
definition.zh: 弯曲处；（尤指解剖学中器官或结构的）屈曲/弯曲部位（含义接近 flexure，但更偏拉丁/技术用语）。

examples.en: The report noted a narrowing near a flexura of the colon.
examples.zh: 报告指出结肠某个弯曲处附近有狭窄。

examples.en: In anatomy, a flexura can describe where a tube-like organ changes direction.
examples.zh: 在解剖学里，flexura 可用来描述管状器官改变走向的位置。

extraExplanation: “flexura”源自拉丁语，核心意思是“弯曲/折曲”。在现代英文中更常用的对应词是 **flexure**（更常见）或 **bend/curve**（更日常）。
在医学与解剖语境里，你更常见到具体搭配，如 **hepatic flexure**（结肠肝曲）与 **splenic flexure**（结肠脾曲）；有些资料可能用较拉丁化的写法（flexura）来表达同类概念。

summary.en: “Flexural” means “related to bending,” especially in engineering and materials science.
summary.zh: “flexural”意为“与弯曲有关的”，多用于工程与材料科学语境。

definition.en: Relating to bending (flexure), especially the bending of a beam, plate, or material under load.
definition.zh: 与弯曲（挠曲）有关的，尤指梁、板或材料在受力下发生的弯曲。

examples.en: Flexural strength measures how much bending force a material can withstand before it breaks.
examples.zh: 抗弯强度衡量材料在断裂前能承受多大的弯曲力。

examples.en: The engineer calculated the flexural stress in the bridge deck.
examples.zh: 工程师计算了桥面板中的弯曲应力。

examples.en: This composite has better flexural performance than ordinary plastic.
examples.zh: 这种复合材料的抗弯性能比普通塑料更好。

extraExplanation: “flexural”常见于工程与材料科学语境，常搭配：flexural strength（抗弯强度）、flexural stiffness/rigidity（抗弯刚度）、flexural stress（弯曲应力）、flexural modulus（弯曲模量）。
它来自“flexure”（弯曲、挠曲），与日常更常见的“flexible（柔韧的）”同源，但“flexural”更偏技术/学术用词。

summary.en: Flexure means a bend or curve, especially in technical contexts such as engineering or anatomy.
summary.zh: Flexure 指“弯曲/弯曲处”，多用于工程、地质或解剖等较正式的语境。

definition.en: A bending or curve; the act or result of bending.
definition.zh: 弯曲；弯曲的动作或结果。

examples.en: The flexure of the metal beam increased under heavy weight.
examples.zh: 金属梁在重压下的弯曲加大了。

examples.en: You can see a gentle flexure in the tree branch after the storm.
examples.zh: 暴风雨过后，你能看到树枝出现了轻微的弯曲。

definition.en: (Anatomy) A bend in a body structure, especially in the intestine (e.g., the hepatic flexure).
definition.zh: （解剖）身体结构中的弯曲处，尤指肠道的弯曲部位（如“肝曲”）。

examples.en: The doctor pointed to the hepatic flexure on the diagram.
examples.zh: 医生在示意图上指出了结肠的肝曲。

examples.en: Pain near a flexure can sometimes be related to digestive issues.
examples.zh: 靠近某个肠曲的疼痛有时可能与消化问题有关。

extraExplanation: “flexure”来自拉丁语词根 *flect-*，意为“弯、折”。同源词有 **flex**（弯曲/伸展）、**flexible**（灵活的、可弯曲的）、**deflect**（偏转）。在日常英语里，人们更常用 **bend** 或 **curve**；“flexure”更偏正式，常见于工程、地质和医学语境。

summary.en: “Flexure-related” means related to bending (flexure), often used in technical or medical contexts.
summary.zh: “flexure-related”意为“与弯曲/屈曲有关的”，常用于技术或医学语境。

definition.en: Connected with, describing, or caused by flexure (bending or curving), especially in a structure, material, or body part.
definition.zh: 与“弯曲/屈曲（flexure）”有关的；用于描述结构、材料或身体部位因弯曲而产生的或与之相关的。

examples.en: The engineer checked the flexure-related cracks in the bridge beam.
examples.zh: 工程师检查了桥梁梁体上与弯曲有关的裂缝。

examples.en: Patients sometimes report flexure-related pain when the joint is bent too far.
examples.zh: 当关节过度弯曲时，患者有时会报告与屈曲有关的疼痛。

examples.en: We ran tests to measure flexure-related stress in the plastic panel.
examples.zh: 我们进行了测试来测量塑料板中的弯曲相关应力。

extraExplanation: “flexure”常见于工程与材料学（梁的弯曲）、解剖学（如 elbow flexure 肘部屈曲）、地质学（地壳受力弯曲）。因此“flexure-related”多出现在技术或医学写作中，日常英语里更常说“bending-related”。
写法上属于复合形容词，通常用连字符：flexure-related + 名词（如 flexure-related stress / damage / injury）。

summary.en: “Flexured” means bent or curved, often in technical descriptions.
summary.zh: “flexured”表示“弯曲的/发生褶皱的”，多用于技术性描述。

definition.en: bent or curved; having a bend or fold (often used in technical or descriptive writing).
definition.zh: 弯曲的；有弯折/褶皱的（常见于技术或描写性语境）。

examples.en: The metal strip was flexured after repeated pressure.
examples.zh: 金属条在反复受压后发生了弯曲。

examples.en: They examined the flexured layers of rock along the cliff.
examples.zh: 他们检查了悬崖边岩层的弯曲褶皱。

definition.en: past form of “flexure”: to bend or cause something to bend (rare in everyday English).
definition.zh: “flexure”的过去式：使弯曲/发生弯曲（日常英语中较少用）。

examples.en: The engineer flexured the thin panel to test its strength.
examples.zh: 工程师把薄板弯折来测试它的强度。

extraExplanation: “flexured”在现代日常英语里不常见，更常见的表达是“bent / curved”。它多出现在地质学（岩层褶皱）、工程材料（受力弯曲）等语境中。
词根来自拉丁语“flex-”（弯曲），同源词包括：flex（弯曲/伸展）、flexible（灵活的/易弯曲的）、reflex（反射/反射动作）。

summary.en: “Flexures” means bends/curves (or bending points), and in linguistics it can mean word inflections.
summary.zh: “flexures”指弯曲/曲折（或弯曲处）；在语言学中也可指词形屈折变化。

definition.en: Bends or curves in something; also, a point where something bends.
definition.zh: 弯曲；弯曲处（也可指弯折的点或部位）。

examples.en: The river’s flexures make the map look like a ribbon.
examples.zh: 这条河的弯曲让地图看起来像一条丝带。

examples.en: Over time, the metal developed small flexures near the joints.
examples.zh: 随着时间推移，金属在连接处附近出现了细小的弯曲。

definition.en: In linguistics, changes in the form of a word (inflections) to show grammar such as tense, number, or case.
definition.zh: （语言学）词形变化（屈折变化），用来表达语法信息，如时态、单复数或格。

examples.en: English has fewer flexures than many languages, but it still uses -s and -ed.
examples.zh: 英语的屈折变化比许多语言少，但仍会用 -s 和 -ed。

examples.en: The student studied verb flexures to understand past tense forms.
examples.zh: 学生学习动词的屈折变化来理解过去时形式。

extraExplanation: “flexures”是“flexure”的复数。日常英语里更常见的词是“bend / curve”（弯曲）或“inflection”（屈折变化）。
词源上与拉丁语 flex-（弯、折）有关，同根词包括“flex”（弯曲、展示肌肉）和“flexible”（灵活的）。在文学或较正式写作中，“flexure(s)”常用来写自然地形（河流、山脊）或结构弯折。

summary.en: “Fley” is a Scottish word meaning “to scare” (and less commonly “a scare”).
summary.zh: “fley”是苏格兰用语，常指“吓到/吓唬”，较少也可指“一次惊吓”。

definition.en: (Scottish, informal) to frighten or scare someone (often suddenly).
definition.zh: （苏格兰用语，非正式）吓唬；使受惊（常指突然吓到人）。

examples.en: Don’t fley the child—she’s already nervous.
examples.zh: 别吓孩子——她已经很紧张了。

examples.en: A loud bang in the hallway fleyed me.
examples.zh: 走廊里一声巨响把我吓了一跳。

definition.en: (Scottish, less common) a sudden fright; a scare.
definition.zh: （苏格兰用语，较少见）惊吓；受惊。

examples.en: That thunder gave me a real fley.
examples.zh: 那声雷真把我吓了一跳。

extraExplanation: “fley”主要见于苏格兰英语（Scots / Scottish English）。在现代标准美式英语里不常用；如果你是在一般英语文本里看到“fley”，也可能是把“flea（跳蚤）”或“flay（剥皮/严厉批评）”拼错了，需要结合上下文判断。

summary.en: “Fleyed” is a Scots dialect word meaning “frightened” or “startled.”
summary.zh: “fleyed”是苏格兰方言词，意思是“害怕的、受惊的”。

definition.en: (Scots / dialect) frightened or startled; scared.
definition.zh: （苏格兰英语/方言）受惊的；害怕的。

examples.en: The sudden bang left the wee lass fleyed.
examples.zh: 突如其来的巨响把小女孩吓了一跳。

examples.en: Don’t be fleyed—it's only thunder.
examples.zh: 别害怕——只是打雷而已。

extraExplanation: “fleyed”常见于苏格兰英语（Scots）与部分英格兰北部方言，通常相当于标准英语的“frightened / scared”。在日常口语、乡土叙事或带地方色彩的文学对话里更常见。
它与苏格兰词“fley”（使受惊、惊吓）有关；你也可能看到写作“fley’t”（表示“fleyed”的缩写/口语拼写）。

summary.en: “Fleyedly” is a rare Scots adverb meaning “in a frightened or timid way.”
summary.zh: “fleyedly” 是少见的苏格兰英语副词，意思是“胆怯地、受惊地”。

definition.en: (Scots, rare) In a frightened, timid, or easily-startled way.
definition.zh: （苏格兰英语，少见）以害怕、胆怯、容易受惊的方式。

examples.en: The horse shied, and the child looked back fleyedly.
examples.zh: 马受惊躲开了，孩子怯生生地回头看。

examples.en: She laughed, but her eyes moved fleyedly toward the dark lane.
examples.zh: 她在笑，但眼睛却怯怯地瞟向那条昏暗的小巷。

extraExplanation: “fleyedly” 来自苏格兰英语里的动词 “fley”（使受惊、吓到）以及形容词 “fleyed”（受惊的、胆怯的）。在现代标准英语中几乎不用；更常见的表达是 “nervously / timidly / fearfully”。
拼写上也常被误写；如果你想表达的是别的词（例如 “fledgling” 初出茅庐的），可以告诉我你的上下文句子，我可以帮你确认。

summary.en: Fleyedness means a frightened, easily scared feeling (mainly Scots).
summary.zh: fleyedness 指“受惊、害怕、易被吓到的感觉”（主要为苏格兰英语用法）。

definition.en: a state of being frightened or easily scared; nervous fear (chiefly Scots/Scottish English, from “fley” = to frighten).
definition.zh: 受惊、害怕的状态；容易被吓到的胆怯感（主要见于苏格兰英语；源自 fley“使害怕/受惊”）。

examples.en: After the sudden bang, she couldn’t hide her fleyedness.
examples.zh: 突然一声巨响后，她怎么也藏不住那种受惊的样子。

examples.en: His fleyedness around dogs comes from a bad childhood experience.
examples.zh: 他见到狗就害怕，是因为小时候有过不好的经历。

extraExplanation: “fleyedness”较少见，更常见的是形容词“fleyed”（被吓到的、受惊的），以及动词“to fley”（吓唬、使受惊）。在苏格兰文学或方言写作中，这类词常用来营造口语/地方色彩。
在标准美式英语里，更常用的表达是“fear,” “fright,” “nervousness,” “being scared,” 或“jumpiness”。

summary.en: “Fleying” is likely a misspelling of “flying,” meaning moving through the air, the act of traveling by aircraft, or the present participle of “fly.”
summary.zh: “fleying”很可能是“flying”的拼写错误，可表示“在空中飞的/会飞的”，也可指“乘飞机/飞行（活动）”，或作动词 fly 的现在分词。

definition.en: moving through the air; able to fly (often used before a noun).
definition.zh: 在空中移动的；会飞的（常作定语）。

examples.en: A flying bird is hard to photograph clearly.
examples.zh: 飞行中的鸟很难拍得清楚。

examples.en: They saw a flying insect near the light.
examples.zh: 他们看到灯旁有一只会飞的昆虫。

definition.en: the activity of traveling in an aircraft; the skill of controlling an aircraft.
definition.zh: 乘飞机旅行；驾驶（飞机）的技能。

examples.en: Flying makes him nervous, especially during takeoff.
examples.zh: 他坐飞机会紧张，尤其是起飞时。

examples.en: She is learning flying at a small airport.
examples.zh: 她正在一座小机场学习飞行（驾驶飞机）。

definition.en: present participle of “fly”: to move through the air; to travel by airplane; to move quickly.
definition.zh: “fly”的现在分词：飞；乘飞机；快速移动。

examples.en: Birds are flying over the river.
examples.zh: 鸟儿正在河上飞。

examples.en: We’re flying to New York tomorrow.
examples.zh: 我们明天乘飞机去纽约。

examples.en: Time is flying this week.
examples.zh: 这周时间过得飞快。

extraExplanation: 你输入的 **fleying** 很可能是拼写错误，常见正确拼法是 **flying**（把 e 去掉，写成 fly + ing）。
“flying”既可以是形容词（flying car 飞行汽车），也可以作名词（go flying 去飞行/坐飞机），还可以是动词 fly 的现在分词（is flying 正在飞）。

summary.en: “Fleyland” isn’t a standard English word; it’s likely a misspelling or a proper name (often “Leyland”).
summary.zh: “fleyland”不是标准英文词；多半是拼写错误或专有名词（常见为“Leyland”）。

definition.en: Not a standard English word; it is likely a misspelling or a name. Common close match: “Leyland” (a place name/surname, e.g., Leyland in England; also in “Leyland cypress”).
definition.zh: 不是标准英文词；更可能是拼写错误或人名/地名。最常见的相近形式是“Leyland”（英格兰地名/姓氏；也用于“Leyland cypress（莱兰柏）”。

examples.en: I couldn’t find “fleyland” in the dictionary—did you mean “Leyland”?
examples.zh: 我在词典里找不到“fleyland”——你是不是想写“Leyland”？

examples.en: Leyland is a town in Lancashire, England.
examples.zh: Leyland是英格兰兰开夏郡的一个城镇。

extraExplanation: “fleyland”本身更像是打字或拼写误差。如果你是在植物/园艺语境看到的，可能指“Leyland cypress”（常见绿篱植物）。如果是在地址、品牌或人名里出现，请告诉我上下文（句子、国家/领域），我可以更准确判断它应是哪一个专有名词或正确拼写。

summary.en: “Fleys” is not standard English; it’s usually a misspelling of “flies.”
summary.zh: “fleys”不是标准英语；通常是“flies”的拼写错误。

definition.en: Not a standard English word; most often a misspelling or nonstandard spelling of “flies” (plural of fly) or “Flays” (a surname/rare proper name).
definition.zh: 不是标准英语单词；最常见是把“flies”（fly 的复数/动词 fly 的三单）拼错，或指“Flays”（姓氏/少见专有名词）。

examples.en: Did you mean “flies” (as in insects) instead of “fleys”?
examples.zh: 你是不是想写“flies”（指苍蝇等昆虫），而不是“fleys”？

examples.en: I think “fleys” is a typo—maybe you meant “flies” in the sentence.
examples.zh: 我觉得“fleys”是拼写错误——也许你在句子里想用的是“flies”。

extraExplanation:
“fleys”在常见词典里一般查不到。如果你能提供一句包含“fleys”的完整句子，我可以根据上下文判断你想表达的是：
1) flies（昆虫：苍蝇/果蝇等；或动词 fly 的第三人称单数），
2) flays（动词 flay：剥皮/痛打，较少见且语气较强），
3) 或某个名字/用户名/地名的拼写。

summary.en: Fleysome (Scots) means disgusting/filthy or frightening/creepy.
summary.zh: Fleysome（苏格兰方言）指“肮脏恶心的”或“吓人阴森的”。

definition.en: (Scots, dialect) Disgusting or filthy; unpleasant to look at or be around.
definition.zh: （苏格兰英语/方言）肮脏恶心的；令人不适、让人不想靠近的。

examples.en: The kitchen was fleysome after the party—dishes everywhere and food on the floor.
examples.zh: 派对结束后厨房变得很fleysome——到处都是盘子，地上还有食物。

examples.en: He refused to touch the fleysome rag without gloves.
examples.zh: 他不戴手套就拒绝碰那块脏得恶心的抹布。

definition.en: (Scots, dialect) Frightening or creepy; making you feel uneasy.
definition.zh: （苏格兰英语/方言）吓人的；阴森的；让人心里发毛的。

examples.en: That old abandoned house looks fleysome at night.
examples.zh: 那栋废弃的老房子到了晚上看起来很fleysome。

examples.en: She told a fleysome story that kept the kids awake.
examples.zh: 她讲了一个很fleysome的故事，把孩子们吓得睡不着。

extraExplanation: “fleysome”多见于苏格兰英语（Scots），也常写作“flysome”。它的核心感觉是“让人反感/发毛”，所以既可以指“脏得恶心”，也可以指“可怕、阴森”。
词源上通常与Scots里的“fley”（吓唬、惊吓）有关；在现代标准英语里不常用，更多出现在苏格兰口语、文学对白或地域描写中，用来营造地方色彩。

summary.en: Flibbertigibbet means a silly, overly talkative, flighty person (often said humorously).
summary.zh: flibbertigibbet 指轻浮爱唠叨、想法跳来跳去的人（常带玩笑语气）。

definition.en: A silly, talkative person who is easily excited and changes opinions quickly; someone flighty and chatty.
definition.zh: 轻浮又爱唠叨的人；容易兴奋、想法变来变去、话很多的人。

examples.en: Stop being such a flibbertigibbet and focus on your homework.
examples.zh: 别这么轻浮唠叨了，专心写作业。

examples.en: In meetings, he can sound like a flibbertigibbet, jumping from idea to idea.
examples.zh: 在会议上，他有时听起来很跳脱，点子一个接一个。

definition.en: (Older use) A frivolous or gossipy person, often used humorously or teasingly.
definition.zh: （较旧用法）爱八卦、轻佻的人，常带开玩笑或调侃语气。

examples.en: She called herself a flibbertigibbet, but she was actually very kind.
examples.zh: 她自称是个爱闹爱聊的人，其实很善良。

examples.en: The novel’s flibbertigibbet aunt brings comic relief to the family scenes.
examples.zh: 小说里那位爱插科打诨的姨妈，为家庭场景增添了喜剧效果。

extraExplanation: 这个词读起来很“绕口”，本身就带有俏皮感，常用于轻松、略带吐槽的语境；如果要更礼貌，可以用 talkative（健谈的）或 chatty（爱聊天的）。
常见文化点：在音乐剧《音乐之声》（The Sound of Music）里，玛丽亚唱到 “I’m a flibbertigibbet! … a will-o’-the-wisp! … a clown!” 让这个词更为人熟知。

summary.en: Flibbertigibbets are people who are very talkative in a silly or gossipy way, often seeming flighty or not serious.
summary.zh: flibbertigibbets 指那些爱碎嘴、轻浮爱八卦、显得不够稳重的人（常带幽默或轻微贬义）。

definition.en: a person who talks a lot in a silly, light, or gossipy way; a flighty chatterbox
definition.zh: 指说话很多但内容轻浮、碎嘴、爱八卦的人；话痨、轻佻的人

examples.en: Stop being such a flibbertigibbet and tell me the important part.
examples.zh: 别这么碎嘴了，先把重点告诉我。

examples.en: The novel’s flibbertigibbet cousin brings gossip to every family dinner.
examples.zh: 小说里那个话多又爱八卦的表亲，每次家庭聚餐都带来一堆流言。

definition.en: a frivolous or irresponsible person who can’t stay serious or focused
definition.zh: 指轻浮不稳重、难以认真或专注的人

examples.en: He acts like a flibbertigibbet at work, so people don’t trust him with big projects.
examples.zh: 他在工作中表现得不稳重，所以大家不敢把大项目交给他。

extraExplanation: “flibbertigibbet”常带一点幽默或轻微贬义，语气比“idiot”这类词温和，更像在说“嘴碎、轻浮、爱插话”。
这个词在莎士比亚《李尔王》(King Lear) 中出现过，用作妖魔/恶灵的名字之一，因此它也带有古旧、文学感；日常口语中不算常见，但很有画面感。

summary.en: Flibbertigibbet (also spelled flibbertigibbety) means a silly, flighty person who talks too much.
summary.zh: Flibbertigibbet（也写作 flibbertigibbety）指轻浮多嘴、话多但不太靠谱的人。

definition.en: A silly, chatty person who talks a lot but is not very sensible (often used in a slightly teasing way).
definition.zh: （常带点打趣）轻浮多嘴的人；话很多但不太靠谱的人。

examples.en: Stop being such a flibbertigibbet and tell me the important part.
examples.zh: 别这么轻浮多嘴了，告诉我重点。

examples.en: He’s kind but a bit of a flibbertigibbet—always jumping from one idea to another.
examples.zh: 他人很好，但有点轻浮多嘴——想法总是跳来跳去。

definition.en: A flighty, silly, or chattering person (sometimes used more strongly, like “scatterbrained”).
definition.zh: （更强调）轻浮浮躁、没定性或叽叽喳喳的人；有点“心不在焉/没头脑”的人。

examples.en: She felt people would label her a flibbertigibbet if she spoke up too much.
examples.zh: 她担心自己话说多了会被人贴上“轻浮多嘴”的标签。

examples.en: In old-fashioned novels, the flibbertigibbet is often a comic character.
examples.zh: 在一些老派小说里，“轻浮多嘴的人”常常是搞笑角色。

extraExplanation: 你写的 **flibbertigibbety** 通常是对标准拼写 **flibbertigibbet** 的变体/误拼；意思基本相同。
这个词带有“古早/文学感”，在现代口语里不算常用，更多用于幽默、调侃或模仿旧式英语。
词源上常被认为与拟声和重复词有关（像 *gibber*“胡言乱语”那样），并因莎士比亚《李尔王》（*King Lear*）中出现过而更有名。

summary.en: A flibustier is a pirate or sea raider; less commonly, it can mean a political obstructer (often expressed in modern English as “filibuster”).
summary.zh: flibustier 指海盗/海上掠夺者；较少见时也可指政治阻挠者（现代英语多用 filibuster 表达）。

definition.en: A pirate, especially one who attacks ships (historically often used for Caribbean “buccaneers” or sea raiders).
definition.zh: 海盗；（尤指历史上在加勒比海一带袭击船只的）海上掠夺者。

examples.en: Stories about flibustiers often describe raids on Spanish treasure ships.
examples.zh: 关于 flibustiers 的故事常常描写他们袭击西班牙运宝船。

examples.en: The novel portrays a flibustier as both adventurous and ruthless.
examples.zh: 这部小说把一名 flibustier 写得既冒险又残忍。

definition.en: A political “freebooter”: a person who obstructs or uses aggressive tactics in politics; in U.S. English this sense is most commonly seen as the related word “filibuster.”
definition.zh: （政治上的）阻挠者；在政治中采取强硬/拖延手段的人（在美式英语里更常见对应词 filibuster）。

examples.en: In older texts, flibustier could refer to a political troublemaker rather than a sea pirate.
examples.zh: 在较早的文本中，flibustier 有时指政治上的捣乱者，而不是真正的海盗。

examples.en: Today, English usually uses “filibuster” for this political meaning.
examples.zh: 如今英语里这种政治含义通常用 “filibuster”。

extraExplanation: 这个词来自法语 flibustier，历史上多指17世纪在加勒比海活动的“海盗/私掠者”。英语里更常见的相关词是 freebooter（掠夺者）与 buccaneer（海盗）。
政治含义与英文 filibuster（议事阻挠）有关：两者在词源上有联系，但在现代英语使用中，flibustier 更偏“海盗”这一层意思。

summary.en: “Flic” is an informal word (often with a movie/old-fashioned feel) meaning a police officer.
summary.zh: “flic”是一个非正式用语，常带电影或老派口吻，意思是“警察”。

definition.en: (Informal, mainly British English) a police officer; a cop.
definition.zh: （非正式，主要英式英语）警察；条子。

examples.en: The flics arrived within minutes and asked everyone to stay back.
examples.zh: 警察几分钟内就到了，并要求大家退后。

examples.en: He ran because he thought the flic would arrest him.
examples.zh: 他逃跑了，因为他以为警察会逮捕他。

extraExplanation: “flic”来自法语俚语，原意指“警察”。在英语里带有口语、略老派/电影感的色彩（常见于侦探片或黑色电影氛围的叙述），语气不如“police officer”正式。
使用时注意场合：在正式写作或对警察当面称呼时，建议用“police officer / officer / the police”，避免显得不礼貌。

summary.en: Flicflac is a gymnastics/acrobatic move—essentially a back handspring.
summary.zh: Flicflac 指体操/杂技动作，基本相当于“后手翻（back handspring）”。

definition.en: a tumbling move in gymnastics or acrobatics where you spring backward and land on your feet, typically passing through a brief hand-support position (often called a “back handspring”).
definition.zh: 体操/杂技中的一种后手翻动作：向后弹跳翻转，通常短暂用手支撑后再落回双脚（常相当于“后手翻”）。

examples.en: She connected a round-off to a flicflac and then finished with a back tuck.
examples.zh: 她做了一个团身转体（round-off）接一个后手翻（flicflac），最后以一个后空翻结束。

examples.en: The coach asked him to practice flicflacs on the spring floor before trying them on the beam.
examples.zh: 教练让他先在弹簧地板上练后手翻（flicflac），再去平衡木上尝试。

extraExplanation: “flicflac”（也常写作 flic-flac）源自法语，在欧洲体操/啦啦队语境里更常见；美式英语里更常说 back handspring。
这个词在日常英语里比较少见，多出现在体操训练、杂技表演、比赛解说或动作编排中。

summary.en: “Flichter” isn’t standard English; it’s most likely a misspelling of “flicker.”
summary.zh: “flichter”不是标准英语词；最可能是把“flicker（闪烁）”拼错了。

definition.en: Not a standard English word. It is most likely a misspelling of “flicker” (to shine or move in an unsteady way), or it may be a surname/name in another language.
definition.zh: 不是标准英语单词。最可能是把“flicker”（闪烁；忽明忽暗地动）拼错了；也可能是其他语言中的姓氏/名字。

examples.en: I think you meant “flicker”: The candle flame began to flicker in the wind.
examples.zh: 我猜你想写的是“flicker”：蜡烛的火焰在风中开始闪烁。

examples.en: The screen started to flicker, so I restarted the computer.
examples.zh: 屏幕开始闪烁，所以我重启了电脑。

extraExplanation:
“flichter”在常见英语词典里通常查不到。如果你是在阅读或听到这个词：
1) 先核对拼写：常见目标词是“flicker”（把 k 写成 ch 很常见的拼写错误）。
2) 也可能是人名/姓氏（尤其来自德语或荷兰语背景），这种情况下意思要看具体人物或语境。
如果你能提供一句原句（上下文），我可以帮你准确判断应是哪个词。

summary.en: “flichtered” is not standard; it likely means “flickered” (shone/moved unsteadily in quick bursts).
summary.zh: “flichtered” 不是标准拼写；很可能是 “flickered”，表示忽明忽暗地闪动/掠过。

definition.en: (Nonstandard spelling) Likely meant “flickered,” the past tense of “flicker”: to shine, move, or appear in quick, unsteady bursts (often of light, images, or feelings).
definition.zh: （非标准拼写）很可能是想写 “flickered”，即 “flicker” 的过去式：指（光、影像或情绪等）快速、断断续续地闪动/出现。

examples.en: The candle flame flickered in the wind.
examples.zh: 蜡烛火焰在风中忽明忽暗地闪动。

examples.en: The lights flickered for a second, then everything went dark.
examples.zh: 灯闪了一下，然后一切都黑了。

examples.en: A look of doubt flickered across her face.
examples.zh: 她脸上掠过一丝怀疑。

definition.en: (Rare/likely misspelling) Sometimes confused with words like “flustered” (confused and nervous) or “filtered” (passed through a filter).
definition.zh: （少见/多半为拼写误差）有时会与 “flustered”（慌乱的）或 “filtered”（被过滤的）混淆。

examples.en: He got flustered when he had to speak in public.
examples.zh: 他在公众场合发言时变得很慌乱。

examples.en: This photo looks filtered and less natural.
examples.zh: 这张照片看起来加了滤镜，不太自然。

extraExplanation: “flichtered” 不是常见英文单词。最接近且最常用的应是 “flickered”。如果你能提供原句（你在哪儿看到/想写的），我可以更准确判断你要表达的是 “flickered / flustered / filtered” 中的哪一个。

summary.en: “Flichtering” is not a standard spelling; you probably mean “flickering,” meaning unsteady, flashing on and off.
summary.zh: “flichtering”不是标准拼写；你很可能想写“flickering”，意思是闪烁、忽明忽暗。

definition.en: (Likely intended) giving an unsteady, quickly changing light, image, or movement; flashing on and off.
definition.zh: （很可能想写）闪烁的；忽明忽暗的；时隐时现的（光、影像或动作不稳定地快速变化）。

examples.en: The candles were flickering in the wind.
examples.zh: 蜡烛在风中闪烁。

examples.en: The old TV screen kept flickering.
examples.zh: 那台旧电视屏幕一直在闪烁。

examples.en: A flickering streetlight made the road look eerie.
examples.zh: 一盏闪烁的路灯让这条路显得有些阴森。

definition.en: present participle of “flicker”: to shine or move in a light, quick, unsteady way; to flash on and off.
definition.zh: “flicker”的现在分词：以轻微、快速、不稳定的方式发光或移动；忽明忽暗。

examples.en: I saw a shadow flickering across the wall.
examples.zh: 我看到一道影子在墙上闪动。

examples.en: Her smile was flickering between confidence and worry.
examples.zh: 她的笑容在自信与担忧之间摇摆不定。

extraExplanation: “flichtering”不是常见英文拼写，最接近的常用词是 **flickering**（闪烁的）。也有人会想写 **flittering**（轻快地飞/掠过，如小鸟或蝴蝶），但在“灯光/屏幕忽明忽暗”的语境里通常用 **flickering**。如果你告诉我句子上下文，我可以帮你确认你想表达的是哪一个。

summary.en: “flichters” is not a standard English word; it is most likely a misspelling of “flickers,” meaning brief, unsteady flashes or quick, slight changes.
summary.zh: “flichters”不是标准英语词；最可能是“flickers”的拼写错误，意思是短暂的闪烁或细微、快速的变化。

definition.en: (Likely) a misspelling of “flickers”: brief, unsteady flashes or quick movements; or the third-person singular form of “flicker.”
definition.zh: （很可能）是“flickers”的拼写错误：指短暂、忽明忽暗的闪烁/微弱跳动；也可指动词“flicker”的第三人称单数形式。

examples.en: The candle flame flickers when the window is open.
examples.zh: 窗户开着时，蜡烛火焰会忽明忽暗地闪烁。

examples.en: A flicker of doubt crossed her face.
examples.zh: 她脸上闪过一丝怀疑。

examples.en: The lights flicker during storms.
examples.zh: 暴风雨时灯会闪烁。

definition.en: “flickers” (as a noun): small quick changes in light, feeling, or movement.
definition.zh: “flickers”（名词）：光线、情绪或动作的细小而短暂的变化。

examples.en: We saw flickers of light in the distance.
examples.zh: 我们看见远处有点点闪光。

examples.en: There were flickers of hope after the good news.
examples.zh: 好消息之后，人们燃起了一丝希望。

extraExplanation: “flichters”不是常见的标准英语单词，我更常见到的是“flickers”（闪烁/闪现）或人名/姓氏（如Fletcher的复数/变体）。如果你是在某篇文章、歌词或游戏里看到“flichters”，可以把原句发我，我能更准确判断它到底指什么。

summary.en: “Flick” means a quick, light movement (or to do it), often with the fingers or wrist; it can also mean quickly switching TV channels or showing a film (informal).
summary.zh: “flick”指轻快、短促的一弹/一甩（或做这个动作）；也可指（非正式）快速换台或放映电影。

definition.en: To move something quickly and lightly with a short, sudden motion (often with the fingers, wrist, or a small tool).
definition.zh: （常用手指/手腕）轻快地一弹；迅速轻拂（使某物突然短促地移动）。

examples.en: She flicked the light switch on.
examples.zh: 她啪地一下把电灯开关拨开了。

examples.en: He flicked dust off his jacket.
examples.zh: 他轻轻一弹，把夹克上的灰尘弹掉。

examples.en: The cat flicked its tail and walked away.
examples.zh: 猫甩了甩尾巴就走开了。

definition.en: A quick, light, sudden movement or touch.
definition.zh: 轻快的一弹；迅速的一甩；短促的动作/触碰。

examples.en: With a flick of his wrist, the card disappeared.
examples.zh: 他手腕一抖，牌就不见了。

examples.en: She gave the page a flick to turn it faster.
examples.zh: 她轻轻一拨，让页面更快翻过去。

definition.en: To show a movie or TV program quickly (informal), or to switch channels quickly.
definition.zh: （非正式）放映（电影/节目）；（尤指）快速换台。

examples.en: They flicked through channels until they found the news.
examples.zh: 他们不停换台，直到找到新闻。

examples.en: The cinema is flicking an old classic tonight.
examples.zh: 今晚影院会放映一部老经典。

extraExplanation: “flick”给人的感觉通常是“轻、快、短促”，比“throw/strike”更不费力，也更小动作。常见搭配：flick on/off（啪地开/关），flick away（弹开/甩开），flick through（快速翻阅/浏览；快速换台）。
名词结构很常见：with a flick of + 名词（手腕/手指/尾巴等），用来描写非常利落的动作，写作里很常见。

summary.en: “Flicked” is the past form of “flick,” meaning to move something quickly and lightly, or to appear briefly (like a smile or light).
summary.zh: “flicked”是“flick”的过去式/过去分词，常指快速轻弹/轻甩某物，或（如微笑、灯光）一闪而过。

definition.en: moved (something) with a quick, light motion, often with a finger or wrist; past tense/past participle of “flick.”
definition.zh: （用很快、很轻的动作）弹动/轻甩（某物）；“flick”的过去式/过去分词。

examples.en: She flicked the light switch and the room went bright.
examples.zh: 她啪地一拨开关，房间就亮了。

examples.en: He flicked a bit of dust off his jacket.
examples.zh: 他把夹克上的一点灰尘轻轻弹掉了。

examples.en: I flicked through the magazine while waiting.
examples.zh: 我等的时候快速翻了翻杂志。

definition.en: (of something like a shadow, image, or emotion) appeared briefly or moved quickly; past tense of “flick.”
definition.zh: （影子、画面、情绪等）一闪而过/掠过；“flick”的过去式。

examples.en: A smile flicked across her face for a second.
examples.zh: 她脸上掠过一丝微笑。

examples.en: Headlights flicked across the wall as the car passed.
examples.zh: 汽车驶过时，车灯的光在墙上一闪而过。

extraExplanation: “flick”常带有“轻、快、短促”的感觉，比“throw/turn/move”更强调动作的小幅度和瞬间性。
常见搭配：flick on/off（啪地开/关）、flick away（弹开/弹走）、flick through（快速翻阅）、flick at（朝……弹/轻甩一下）。
文学/叙述里常用“a smile flicked across…”来表现情绪短暂出现，语气比“smiled”更克制、更瞬间。

summary.en: Flicker means to shine or appear unsteadily, or to appear briefly (like a light, shadow, or emotion).
summary.zh: Flicker 指（光/影像）忽明忽暗地闪烁，也可指（情绪/表情）短暂地一闪而过。

definition.en: (of a light or image) to shine or appear unsteadily, turning on and off quickly or changing brightness.
definition.zh: （灯光或影像）忽明忽暗地闪烁；时亮时灭。

examples.en: The candle flickered in the wind.
examples.zh: 蜡烛在风中闪烁。

examples.en: The old hallway light keeps flickering.
examples.zh: 走廊那盏旧灯一直在忽明忽暗。

examples.en: Her face flickered on the screen for a second, then disappeared.
examples.zh: 她的脸在屏幕上闪了一下就消失了。

definition.en: to move quickly and lightly, often with small repeated movements.
definition.zh: 轻快地快速移动；（尤指）轻轻地来回摆动/掠过。

examples.en: A lizard’s tongue flickered in and out.
examples.zh: 蜥蜴的舌头快速地伸进伸出。

examples.en: Shadows flickered across the wall as cars passed by.
examples.zh: 汽车驶过时，影子在墙上掠过。

definition.en: (of a feeling or expression) to appear briefly and then disappear.
definition.zh: （情绪或表情）一闪而过；短暂出现又消失。

examples.en: A smile flickered across his face.
examples.zh: 他脸上掠过一丝微笑。

examples.en: Doubt flickered in her eyes.
examples.zh: 她眼里闪过一丝怀疑。

definition.en: an unsteady flash or quick change in light; a brief, wavering appearance.
definition.zh: 闪烁；（光的）忽明忽暗；短暂而不稳定的显现。

examples.en: The bulb gave a flicker and went out.
examples.zh: 灯泡闪了一下就灭了。

examples.en: I saw a flicker of light under the door.
examples.zh: 我看到门底下有一丝闪动的光。

definition.en: a brief, slight appearance of a feeling or idea.
definition.zh: （情感或想法的）一丝；一闪念。

examples.en: There was a flicker of hope.
examples.zh: 有一丝希望。

examples.en: For a flicker of a moment, he looked afraid.
examples.zh: 有那么一瞬间，他看起来有点害怕。

extraExplanation: “flicker”常和“蜡烛/火焰/灯泡/屏幕”搭配，强调“不稳定、断断续续”。如果是稳定的闪光，更常用“flash”。
常见搭配：flicker on/off（忽亮/忽灭），flicker out（闪烁后熄灭），a flicker of + 情绪/抽象名词（如 hope, doubt, anger）表示“短暂出现的一丝……”。

summary.en: Flicker-free means a screen or light does not show noticeable flickering, making it more comfortable for the eyes.
summary.zh: Flicker-free指屏幕或灯光没有明显闪烁，通常更护眼、看起来更舒适。

definition.en: Not showing visible flickering (rapid changes in light or brightness), especially in a screen, display, or light; designed to reduce eye strain.
definition.zh: 无可见闪烁的（亮度快速变化）；尤指屏幕/显示器/灯光为减少闪烁以降低眼疲劳而设计。

examples.en: This monitor has a flicker-free backlight, so it’s easier on my eyes at night.
examples.zh: 这台显示器采用无闪烁背光，所以晚上看起来更不伤眼。

examples.en: Look for flicker-free LED bulbs if you get headaches from certain lights.
examples.zh: 如果你会因某些灯光而头痛，可以选购无闪烁的LED灯泡。

examples.en: The laptop’s flicker-free display is helpful for long study sessions.
examples.zh: 这台笔记本的无闪烁屏幕对长时间学习很有帮助。

extraExplanation: “flicker-free”常见于产品参数/营销用语（如显示器、手机屏幕、LED灯）。它通常指采用直流调光（DC dimming）或高频PWM调光，使人眼不容易察觉闪烁；但“无闪烁”并不一定意味着在所有亮度下都完全没有闪烁。
连字符形式flicker-free多作定语：a flicker-free screen/light；也可作表语：The screen is flicker-free.

summary.en: “Flickered” means shone or appeared unsteadily (like a light), or appeared briefly (like an emotion).
summary.zh: “flickered”表示（光/影像）闪烁不定，或（情绪/表情）一闪而过。

definition.en: (of a light or image) to shine or appear unsteadily, quickly turning on and off or changing brightness.
definition.zh: （灯光或影像）忽明忽暗；闪烁不定。

examples.en: The candle flickered in the wind.
examples.zh: 蜡烛在风中闪烁不定。

examples.en: The old TV screen flickered for a moment and then went dark.
examples.zh: 老电视屏幕闪了一下，随后就黑了。

definition.en: (of a feeling or expression) to appear briefly and then disappear.
definition.zh: （情绪或表情）一闪而过；短暂出现后消失。

examples.en: A look of fear flickered across his face.
examples.zh: 他脸上掠过一丝恐惧。

examples.en: Hope flickered in her eyes when she heard the news.
examples.zh: 听到消息时，她眼里闪过一丝希望。

definition.en: (of movement) to move quickly and lightly, often in small, sudden motions.
definition.zh: （动作）轻快地快速掠过；（常指小而突然的）闪动。

examples.en: A shadow flickered across the wall.
examples.zh: 一道影子在墙上掠过。

examples.en: Her fingers flickered over the piano keys.
examples.zh: 她的手指在琴键上飞快地跳动。

extraExplanation: “flickered”是动词 flicker 的过去式/过去分词。常见搭配：lights/candles flicker（灯光/烛光闪烁），a smile/feeling flickers（微笑/情绪一闪而过），screen flickers（屏幕闪烁，可能表示信号或电源不稳）。
语感对比：blink 多用于“眼睛眨”或“灯一亮一灭很清晰的开关式闪”；flicker 更强调“不稳定、抖动、忽明忽暗”的感觉，更有画面感，文学描写里也很常见。

summary.en: “Flickering” describes unsteady, quickly changing light or movement, and it can also mean a brief, passing feeling (like a flicker of hope).
summary.zh: “flickering”常指光或火忽明忽暗、闪烁不定；也可比喻短暂掠过的情绪或念头（如一丝希望）。

definition.en: Shining or burning unsteadily, with quick small changes in brightness (often about light, flames, or screens).
definition.zh: （光、火焰或屏幕等）忽明忽暗的，闪烁不定的。

examples.en: The candle gave off a flickering light.
examples.zh: 蜡烛发出忽明忽暗的光。

examples.en: My computer screen is flickering again.
examples.zh: 我的电脑屏幕又开始闪烁了。

examples.en: We walked down the hallway under flickering fluorescent lights.
examples.zh: 我们在闪烁的荧光灯下走过走廊。

definition.en: The act or process of moving or shining with quick, light, repeated changes (often used as a noun).
definition.zh: （常作名词）快速、轻微、反复的闪动或闪光的过程。

examples.en: There was a flickering of light behind the curtains.
examples.zh: 窗帘后面有一阵光的闪动。

examples.en: He noticed the flickering on the old TV.
examples.zh: 他注意到那台老电视在闪烁。

definition.en: Present participle of “flicker”: to shine, burn, or move unsteadily in quick, small changes.
definition.zh: “flicker”的现在分词：指（光/火/影子等）闪烁；（情绪/想法等）一闪而过。

examples.en: The fire was flickering in the wind.
examples.zh: 火在风中摇曳闪烁。

examples.en: A smile was flickering across her face.
examples.zh: 她脸上掠过一丝微笑。

extraExplanation: “flicker”常用于描写氛围：烛光、火光、霓虹灯、电影画面等，给人一种不稳定、带点神秘或紧张的感觉。
除了真实的光线，也常用作比喻：a flicker of hope/interest（“一丝希望/兴趣”），强调“很短暂、很微弱”。

summary.en: “Flickeringly” means “in a flickering way,” with quick, uneven changes in light or appearance.
summary.zh: “flickeringly”表示“以闪烁的方式”，指明暗或状态快速、不均匀地变化。

definition.en: In a way that flickers—shining or moving with quick, irregular changes (often of light, flame, or an image).
definition.zh: 以闪烁的方式；明暗或状态快速、不规则地变化（常指光、火焰或画面）。

examples.en: The candle burned flickeringly in the drafty room.
examples.zh: 在有穿堂风的房间里，蜡烛忽明忽暗地燃着。

examples.en: On the old screen, the picture appeared flickeringly and then went dark.
examples.zh: 在旧屏幕上，画面断断续续地闪烁着，随后变黑了。

extraExplanation: “flickeringly”来自动词“flicker”（闪烁、摇曳）+ 副词后缀“-ly”，表示“以……的方式”。常见搭配有：burn/shine/glow flickeringly（摇曳地燃烧/发光），appear flickeringly（断续地出现）。
语体上偏书面或描写性写作；日常口语更常说“it was flickering”或“it kept flickering”（它一直在闪）。

summary.en: “Flickermouse” is not a standard modern English word; it’s usually a username or a playful/incorrect variant of “flittermouse” meaning “bat.”
summary.zh: “flickermouse”不是现代标准英语词；通常是网名，或是“flittermouse”（意为“蝙蝠”）的戏谑/误拼变体。

definition.en: (Nonstandard/rare) A bat; often seen as a misspelling or playful variant of the older word “flittermouse.”
definition.zh: （非标准/罕见）蝙蝠；常被视为古老词“flittermouse”的误拼或戏谑变体。

examples.en: In some old-fashioned or playful writing, a “flickermouse” may mean a bat flying at dusk.
examples.zh: 在一些古风或玩笑式的写法里，“flickermouse”可能指黄昏时飞行的蝙蝠。

examples.en: I thought “flickermouse” was a real animal name, but the common word is “bat” (or the older “flittermouse”).
examples.zh: 我以为“flickermouse”是正式的动物名称，但常用词是“bat”（或较古老的“flittermouse”）。

definition.en: A made-up name (often a username/handle) rather than a standard dictionary word.
definition.zh: 多为自造名称（常见于网名/用户名），并非标准词典词条。

examples.en: “Flickermouse” is my online handle for gaming.
examples.zh: “Flickermouse”是我打游戏用的网名。

examples.en: Search results for “flickermouse” mostly point to people’s usernames, not a dictionary definition.
examples.zh: 搜索“flickermouse”的结果多是用户名，而不是词典释义。

extraExplanation: “flittermouse”是英语里一个较古老的词，字面意思接近“飞来飞去的老鼠”，源于人们早期对蝙蝠外形的联想；现代英语中一般直接说“bat”。
如果你在文本里看到“flickermouse”，很多时候是拼写变体、玩笑写法或昵称；正式写作建议用“bat”，想要古风/文学感可用“flittermouse”。

summary.en: Flickerproof means made to prevent flickering in light or screens; rarely, it can mean emotionally steady.
summary.zh: Flickerproof 指防闪烁（让灯光/屏幕更稳定）；少见时可比喻“坚定稳定”。

definition.en: Designed or made to prevent flicker (small, rapid changes in light or image), so the light/screen looks steady.
definition.zh: （设备/产品）防闪烁的；避免光线或画面快速明暗变化，看起来更稳定。

examples.en: This desk lamp is flickerproof, so it’s more comfortable for long study sessions.
examples.zh: 这盏台灯是防闪烁的，所以长时间学习更舒服。

examples.en: Many newer monitors advertise flickerproof technology to reduce eye strain.
examples.zh: 许多新款显示器宣传防闪烁技术，以减轻眼睛疲劳。

definition.en: (Figurative, less common) Stable and not likely to waver or weaken.
definition.zh: （比喻，较少用）坚定稳定的；不容易动摇的。

examples.en: She stayed flickerproof in her support for her friend.
examples.zh: 她对朋友的支持始终坚定不移。

extraExplanation: “flickerproof”多见于产品文案与科技语境（如台灯、LED灯、显示器、摄像灯）。有些屏幕/灯具会因PWM（脉宽调制）等方式调光而产生肉眼不易察觉的闪烁；“flickerproof / flicker-free”通常表示通过直流调光或高频调光等方式降低闪烁，从而提升舒适度与拍摄效果。
拼写上也常见连字符写法：flicker-proof；含义不变。与之类似的市场用语还有“flicker-free”（无闪烁/低闪烁）。

summary.en: “Flickers” usually means something shines or appears briefly and unsteadily (light, screens, or emotions), and it can also be the plural noun for brief flashes.
summary.zh: “flickers”常指（光、屏幕或情绪）短暂且不稳定地出现/闪烁；也可作名词复数，表示点点闪光或短暂信号。

definition.en: (of a light, screen, or flame) to shine unsteadily, quickly turning on and off or changing brightness.
definition.zh: （光、屏幕或火焰）忽明忽暗；闪烁不定。

examples.en: The candle flickers in the wind.
examples.zh: 蜡烛在风中忽明忽暗。

examples.en: The old TV screen flickered for a second.
examples.zh: 那台旧电视屏幕闪了一下。

definition.en: (of a feeling or expression) to appear briefly and then disappear.
definition.zh: （情绪或表情）一闪而过；短暂浮现又消失。

examples.en: A smile flickered across her face.
examples.zh: 她脸上掠过一丝微笑。

examples.en: Doubt flickered in his eyes.
examples.zh: 他的眼里闪过一丝怀疑。

definition.en: The plural form of “flicker,” meaning brief, unsteady flashes of light or quick, slight movements.
definition.zh: “flicker”的复数：指闪烁的光点/短暂闪光，或轻快、细微的快速动作。

examples.en: We saw flickers of light behind the trees.
examples.zh: 我们看到树林后面有点点闪光。

examples.en: Only a few flickers appeared on the radar.
examples.zh: 雷达上只出现了几处短暂信号。

extraExplanation: “flicker”常用来描写两类画面：一是物理的光（蜡烛、霓虹灯、屏幕）“不稳定地亮”，二是心理/情感“短暂出现”。文学里很常见，比如“a flicker of hope（希望的一丝火花）”“a flicker of fear（恐惧的一闪）”，用来营造细微但有力量的变化。
